25557462.review:
It's a great game with very satisfying gameplay.

I will give one caveat: DO NOT PLAY FOR THE STORY. IT IS TERRIBLE. This is the main problem I have with this game and the other games in this series.

I mean, the campaign itself is fine and great fun to play and I would HIGHLY suggest playing it, but just do yourself a favor and either skip the ancient aliens plot, just ignore it or don't get ajita whenever someone makes a terrible space story like I do. Some of the ideas brought up in the game are interesting, but I personally didn't like the end narrative.

Another thing to note is despite the story being terrible, it isn't forced down your throat to the point that it detracts from the game. It's just something that's basically there, really. Without it, you're building towers to shoot liquid. This is FUN in itself, desperately trying to hold back the flood of death. The story feels more like its just there just because it needed some sort of story besides "there's death liquid that will fuck up your shit that you need to shoot". For this purpose, the story does fine.

All in all, I'm satisfied by the decision to purchase this game. I find myself coming back to play it every once and a while. The player made levels, especially the Play As Creeper levels change up the game.

Gameplay: 9/10
Story: Aloha+2/The Martian (1/10)

25337048.review:
One of my all time favourite games. Probably the most original and replayable tower defense out there. Single player it can stand tall together with strategy games like starcraft or age of empires without shame. 

100% achievments took me 450 hours. I suppose it can be done in half that time. 

There are tons more content even after the achievements. The biggest problem is probably how the ruleset is almost identical on every map.

Suggestions for the creator. Multplayer: Allow comments on map. Notify players when their map has a comment or time is beaten. Notify players when their time is beaten. List maps with newly beaten highscores. Rank players on how many 1st rank they have on maps. Chatroom? There is SO much that can be done for a competetive multiplayer scene in this game. The current DMD is pretty bare bones. Go steal some inspiration from super mario maker or similar. (How about co-op maps? Too difficult?)

Map making: Ditch the obscure scripting language for javascript or similar. Allow multiple map campaigns that allows some progression. Where the outcome in one map can affect following maps. For example custom tech tree unlocked over several maps like in the original campaign. Or campaigns where the final map can be played from start, but can be made easier if you choose to beat other maps before it. Or variable prices, or unit prices or unit strength. Or pretty much anything to mix up the normal gameplay. 

I think this gameplay is too unique to just let it sit and spoil. Please go make a sequel. Please.

25152941.review:
The Creeper series is in a sort-of RTS style, with no AI. Creeper is represented as a blue fluid that damages player structures when it comes in contact with them. It spawns at set intervals, gradually filling the entire map if left alone. The general objective in Creeper World 3 is to battle through the Creeper and destroy the spawners by building nullifiers next to them.

The game can get quite challenging, and perhaps impossible, if the player has trouble getting enough resource production to output enough damage to Creeper before it engulfs the player's base. Like any RTS, there is a build order to learn and practice, but one key difference is the pause button, resulting in a less intense "RTS" game. There are hundreds of hours of gameplay, not including user-created custom levels. Nice concept and fairly engaging story.

The original concept for Creeper World 3 can be found on Armor Games, where a series is dedicated to the blue fluid, so start with those shorter titles if you're not ready for Creeper World 3.

25140916.review:

25127094.review:
Some are calling this tower defence. I'd call it real-time strategy. Regardless, I don't normally like tower defence or RTS, but this game is the exception to both. Maybe that's because this game takes those ideas and adds a simple but robust concept for the enemy units that you're fighting against.

The best news for you is that you can play a free demo of all the Creeper World games on the web via Flash or Unity webplayer. If you want to find out what people are gushing about, just go try the demo. You don't have to download anything (other than the browser plugin), just play it in your browser. If you like tower defence or RTS, definitely play the demo. Even if you don't, but you're somehow reading this out of curiosity for this game, try the demo anyway. Take it from a guy who normally dislikes both of those genres, and just look at how many hours I've played Creeper World III.

This is essentially a much-improved version of the first Creeper World. The game has a built-in map editor, and also seed-based procedural generation for random maps. This is in addition to hundreds of pre-made maps of varying difficulty.

As of the time of this writing, this game still has an active community of dedicated and gifted players who are still adding custom maps each day. There is much opportunity for modding. In addition to the map editor, there is a built-in scripting language so you can essentially reprogram the game (within limitations I imagine, as I've never personally experimented with it), and I've seen players come up with some very creative ideas such as maps where you play as the Creeper and maps where the enemy has units similar to your own that are controlled by AI, maps with fog of war, maps with booby traps, and the list goes on. The mods and customization make available endless hours of entertainment.

24812063.review:
[h1]One of the best strategy games on Steam[/h1]

Many survival/strategy games are like drowning. Such games play out as a constant desperate struggle to stay above water, with no chance to breathe, until you are eventually overwhelmed and die a horrible death.

[i]Creeper World 3[/i] is more like walking a tight-rope. At any time you can pause, catch your breath, and steady yourself for the next step. The risk is when you start moving. It is always a delicate balance - if you go too fast and overextend yourself, you will lose ground instead of gaining it. [b]This is strategy at its best[/b].

[b]If drowning sounds like more fun, don't play this game - it isn't for you.[/b]

The diverse selection of units - each with its own distinct role - enables several rewarding strategies. The level terrain and enemy placement strongly impact tactics, so every mission feels distinct.

The game includes more missions than you will ever play, a level editor for making even more missions and sharing with the community, and an option for procedurally-generated levels as well. You will [i]never[/i] run out of content.

[i]Creeper World 3[/i] features satisfying and refreshing mechanics you will find in no other game. My first experience with it was overwhelmingly enjoyable. As I mastered the mechanics, it felt less novel but no less satisfying. Years later, I still dedicate time every month to purging more creeper.

24660484.review:
An interesting game mechanic, following the idea of creating some seemingly unstoppable wave of "goo" that breakes down all matter, except the terrain (game logic), which flows inexorably towards you and your base, for seemingly no reason at all. 

When you first enter the game, the "goo" is terrifying, simply because you can't really identify it as a paticular entity, it simply lacks similarity to what most people are used to in a tower defence. However, actually having to move towers and lines of defence to push back this mass, creates a game where once you understand just how to turtle up correctly in the early stages of a mission and then build up your eco to allow you to push the goo back, eventually results in a slow slog of a misson until you eventually reach your target and power it up.

And yet, despite this I have to recommend the game, simply because I enjoyed, and I think other people would too, if only because the game mechanics are unique and well executed. In regards to the pacing of the missions, you can only really take two routes, Turtle up, or rush to a chokepoint in the middle of a map. 

So if you want a change of pace from the usual wave by wave, monster after monster TD, then I couldn't recommend this game more.

24457195.review:
[h1] TL:DR	[/h1] - It's a good strategy game, well polished with few issues if any, and it's quite fun, it's worth the money, and will offer many hours of gameplay with thousands of missions to choose from, including player made missions.

This game is very much worth both the money spent buying it and the time spent playing it. It is a major time sink, hours go by without me even noticing. There's hundreds, even thousands of different maps and missions to choose from.
Personally my favourite section is the player made custom maps and missions, they feature many different scenarios and events, even some new things not present in the base game like new units and new enemies. It's really great seeing all these things people have made, there's strategic maps people have made where you have to plan ahead and think carefully, wacky maps that are fun and light hearted, play as creeper maps where the role is reversed and you are the creeper assaulting a base, custom scenarios of different kinds made by people, it's all varied and quite fun to play.

Another feature is a random map generator, where you put in the features you want, like map size, terrain type, and other variables, and the generator will create a random map based on what you want from it. For people who want a challenge, there's a section of the game dedicated to randomly made extremely difficult maps, some of which are literally impossible, others close to that. Most of them can be done, but they require a lot of thought and careful action to get there. For people who want a more casual experience there's a section dedicated to easier maps that have items called "artifacts of Odin", and the goal is to collect these items scattered throughout the various planets. There's also a campaign which features some interesting levels which teach you the game, some of which are quite tricky.

The premise is that there's this entity called the creeper, that has been ravaging the universe for a long time. It spreads from planet to planet, creeping across like a liquid, and it is your job to simultaneously put up a strong defence to hold back the tide and to also effectively assault the source of this enemy. It's a cross between a tower defence, real time strategy and management sim all in one. You have to position your units, manage supply lines, organise your base, respond to the changes of the battle, manage your resources, extend out in an effort to attack whilst at the same time making sure your defences will hold. You have to be careful with what you do and choose a playstyle, do you turtle up, building up a strong defence capable of weathering the incoming assault at the cost of allowing the creeper to multiply thus causing future expansion to be slower, or do you reach out early for a preemtive strike, weakening the creeper early or gaining a strong foothold, at the risk of overextending and leaving gaps or weaker parts of your defence? There are different ways of playing this all depending on your own individual playstyle and what is better for the map you are playing.

You can play this at your own pace, there's the option to play it at normal speed, 2X, 3X or 4X speed, and you can also pause the game and issue orders whilst paused, useful for assessing the situation on a large map where a lot of things are happening at once and you need to be controlling the battlefield in all these areas simultaneously.

In terms of stability, this game is very stable, there's few bugs (I'm not even sure I've noticed any), it runs well and doesn't require high specs. It's a lot better in this regard than many big name titles made by whole studios, and this was afaik made by one person. 
There's a fair amount of UI options and a few graphical options which are all quite nice to have.

Verdict:
Buy it, especially if it's on sale!

Pros:
- Relaxing, yet rewarding, RTS experience
- Campaign missions are interesting and unique
- 100+ hours to complete the campaign missions (probably, not done yet)
- Map maker
- Community-made maps
- Random map generator (a.k.a. Dial Map Device)

Cons:
- Storytelling tries to be way too "epic" but is simply tedious (maybe the later missions will make up for it?)

Review:
This game is a perfect match for me. It's an RTS, but you basically set your own pace, so it's much less stressful than something like StarCraft. Don't get me wrong, I love StarCraft, but Creeper World 3 somehow manages to make the RTS experience relaxing and rewarding at the same time.

At the time of writing this review I have about 19 hours in the game, and I've barely scratched the surface of the content available. I'm maybe 1/4 of the way through the campaign missions, and have yet to play any of the thousands of player-made maps, or the practically infinite map generator called Dial Map Device.

The campaign missions are interesting, and somehow keep surprising me with new challenges. The storytelling is pretty bad, though. I feel like writer tried too hard to make it feel like a super epic novel, but it just ends up being tedious.

Overall it has been well worth the $2.99 I paid for it. Having experienced it, I would have easily paid full price for it.

It's an okay game. The mechanics are a fun take on the traditional tower defense game, and there are a lot of different buildings available. However, the game turns into a grind fest after you stabilize on a level. The formula is: buy as much econ as you can without dying, then at the last second buy towers to keep yourself alive. Sometimes this is difficult, but I rarely lost levels except for when the layout was something I hadn't seen before (for example, some levels have space between usable areas of land). As long as you don't overbuild, there are almost no scenarios where a previously defended area will get overwhelmed. It would be nice if there was better scaling over time or perhaps momentum mechanics (so if you screw up while expanding it can cause damage to the rest of your structure). 

I'm probably only 1/3rd of the way through the game, but it's gotten a bit too repetitive to see through. Oh well. 

Don't recommend unless you're looking for a side game while watching netflix or something.

24192006.review:
RECOMMENDED WITH WARNINGS

I am frustrated with this game. Because:

When I first started playing it I thought it was going to be my new favorite game. And it was for like a week. But of course the "introductory phase" is never the same as when you get into the "meat" of a game, and that's where things got frustrating.

Mainly cuz it's just boring. Feels like a game in search of an x-pack (at [i]least[/i] one x-pack!) 

Not enough diversity in terms of friendly or enemy units/activities = not enough diversity in gameplay overall = game gets boring real quick.

Map-wise, no complaints about the amount of content. There are hundreds if not thousands of maps I have not played, and theoretically unlimited content via parametric map generator and fan-made content. But the actual gameplay is so boring I would basically have to force myself to play it at this point. (Achievements, u know...)

The usual response to the "boring" complaint is that "you are playing it wrong". (IKR?) People apparently get a kick out of playing this game in a "speed run" style, because high scores are based on speed. At that point, though, it becomes more of a puzzle game and those just don't interest me at all. (Or at least, they interest me [i]extremely[/i] rarely...)

One thing that might alleviate the tedium a little is if there was smarter UI logic/assistance when it came to placing your collectors (basically solar power plants which you have to at least attempt to place somewhat optimally or they are useless). Right now you can semi-automatically lay them out in a line. This game would be less unjust vs. humanity if you could quickly lay them out in a grid. (i.e. keep the exact capabilities of the current placement "tool" and just make it work in 2 dimensions instead of just 1.) I find myself spending a lot of time doing these tedious set-ups at the beginning of each map, that practically take as long as the gameplay portion.

But of course the pros are like "you are not supposed to be building 200 collectors and spending 45 minutes on a single map!"  OK, but even when I play short games, the setup takes too long.

........

[b]So, while I ultimately don't "NOT RECOMMEND" this game

-- as critical as I am, it actually takes a LOT for me to "NR" --

if [i]I[/i] was looking for a pure Tower/RTS-defense kinda game... [i]I'd[/i] appreciate the advice if someone told me my time was probably better spent elsewhere.[/b]

(And that being said, I'm not 100% sure but I think I got this game in a bundle and probably effectively paid <$2 for it so .. not like I rly regret buying it anyway. I just regret becoming infatuated with it before I knew what it really was.)

In Creepers your constantly under attack from a constant flow of blue mass, rather than the traditional waves of enemies, it's your task to hold it back while gathering items or force you way into the mass, to blow it all up.

creepers is a breath of fresh tower-defense-air, every level present you with an interesting story and exiting challenges, the play style is casual, build your defense and slowly progress towards your goals, this game is really about defense, there's nothing more enjoyable, than slowly progressing into the 'blue' by moving towers, shoot a path, build platforms and repeat, sounds a bit boring?, but it's far from it. 

Creepers is all game mechanics, something it does very very well, graphics is not worth talking about, like in Prison architecture it does it's job and works flawless, it's not in the way and you quickly forget about it, still i would like to see some improvement here.

The campaign offers hours of challenging game-play, if that's not enough for, there are hundreds of levels build by users.

so why not 10 of 10, on game-play i'll give it a 9.5, but this is the third game in the series, you would think by now graphics would be on the agenda, especially the interface, which is a big mess, it never went beyond the mockup stage, which is sad, because it sends a signal that "we just don't care", they should.

there are much more to be said about Creepers, but honestly i'll rather play the game than write about it, so off i go.

if you like tower defense games and games like Infested planet, this one is for you, but be warned, it is a time-robber ;).

A novel take on the tower defense genre.

The campaign is kinda short, but there are TONS of levels beyond those.  Some are user-created, some procedurally made, and a lot of extras from the devs.

23836060.review:
Bringing something new to the tower defense genre, Creeper World is ultimately about logistics. the key to every level involves establishing and expanding a production base of energy and ore, building and defending a transportation network to bring those materiasl to where they are needed, and deploying a variety of defensive systems to repulse a predictable but overwhelmingly endless flow of purple goo.

Graphics are simple yet functional, soundtrack is good but repetitious and the game lacks any voiceovers. In a stricly technical sense, this game belongs in the 90s. However, the excellent design and level of refinement more than make up for the lack of luster and polish.

All in all, it would be a decent buy at the price asked ($15) as of this review, but it's currently (Summer 2016 Sale) $3, which should make this a no brainer for any tower defense fan,

22075584.review:
8/10. Excellent tower variation, map variation, and general enjoyment. See expanded below.

Did you know this thing's earlier installments are available as flash games? That's how I first started playing th Creeper saga, and when I ran across this one on steam, I bought it without a second thought. That happened to be a great purchase that I have long enjoyed. 

In this game, you take on the role of the universes ultimate tower-defence gamer, protecting your command centers from an ever increasing biomass of pure evil long enough to extract data from the doomed planet and warp to the next system. The tower defence aspect of this game is great, with new weapons, reactos, and offensive technology unlocking progessively and adding more and more layers to the game as the difficulty ramps up.

There is a story, which is what's driving you to keep playing missions: the promise of destroying the un-destroyable Creeper once and for all. Guided by a redoubtable A.I, your lone ship treks across the galaxy trying to unraval the mystery of the Creeper.

Overall, a solid game. After the campaign is an endless array of maps, some dev made and countless other community made. The repetitivness of mission objectives can get boring,  but put it down and come back tomorrow and you'll keep having fun.

21589390.review:
[h1]Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal [/h1] 

I think that Creeper World 3; Arc Eternal may be one of the greatest games that currently exist. I will add a TL;DR at the end.

[h1]Gameplay [/h1] 

Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a perfect mix of RTS and Tower Defense along with aspects of slight management. You fight against a liquid like and versatile foe known as Creeper. This game has infinite, and I do mean nearly infinite replayability. Once you finish the base story you can go and do thousands of more missions created by the creators and the community. This is the best strategy game I have ever played. There is not much in this world like being completely surrounded by Creeper and slowly, ever so slowly pushing back and destroying every last piece of it. There are tons of ways to beat levels whether you want to attack swiftly with risk or play for a longer game to build your layout to counteract the ever attacking foe. You can even create anti-creeper or terraform the land around you to add even more to this games amazing functions. Overall this game has a very unique and formidable foe and is the best and one of the most exhilarating strategy games I have ever played. 

[h1]Graphics/Sounds [/h1] 

I love the look of the creeper, weaponry, even the terrain. The music fits with the game giving an adventurous and formidable feel of the unknown. 

[h1]Pros/Cons [/h1] 

[b] Pros [/b] 

+ Unique game playstyle 
+ Enormous amount of replayability 
+ Addicting 
+ Ranges from super easy to maps where you will wonder who was sadistic enough to make it
+ Huge amount of maps to play
+ Good story
+ Map editor

[b]Cons [/b] 

- May becomes repetitive to some

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1] 

I remember playing the first Creeper World on kongregate and thinking "I love this game, holy crap it's amazing". Next came Creeper World 3: Abraxis and I played it the moment it was available and again loved it but wished there was more than the 12 missions and then around a year later I got Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal on steam.  I love the game, just love it. This is definitely one of my favourite games to ever play. I also found out a while ago a new game which I think is called Particle Fleet is being developed by Knuckle Cracker and I really hope it makes its eventual way onto steam since it looks amazing. This game to me is a piece of true satisfaction and fun. This is a mix of two of my favourite types of games which are RTS and Tower Defense and it has combined those two perfectly in my opinion.

[h1]TL;DR [/h1] 

Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a great mix of RTS and Tower Defense games. It has a unique and constantly attacking foe known as the Creeper and is an astounding strategy game. If you are unsure whether to get this game or not check out Creeper World 3: Abraxis on kongregate to get an idea of the basics of the game and general gameplay.

This game is wonderful. I bought it a long time ago and thought I'd try it out yesterday. My goodness, this is an amazing game. I've only cleared 3 star systems, but I have thoroughly enjoyed how this game had me looking at my clock, realizing I have work to do, but still wanted to complete "one more level."

This game combines tower defense mechanics and your traditional real time strategy games where you are on the frontal assault. You create power systems, linked together a supply grid you create, adding weapons structures and such to fight back the creeping enetity, creeper. It combines wonderful elements of strategic challenge and planning, since the creeper is constantly spreading toward you and your base, you often have to act fast to set up power facillities and defenses before you can press forward. I haven't found it terribly difficult so far. I have a habit of using more energy than I can produce before I spam reactors (need to work on that). I enjoy how each level throws new mechanics to aid and threaten you further. But otherwise, this game has been a wonderful rentry for me into a genre (RTS) I have driffted away from over the years.

10/10 would have my base blown up by spores again.

20950463.review:
[h1]Because of this game Steam is convinced that I like Tower Defence games...
I don't, I just like Creeper World series, that's it.[/h1]

In Creeper World games, you set up energy collection grid and use collected energy to beat back titular creeper, the blue, oozing fluid whose behaviour (according to extras from CW1) is described by modified heat transfer equations. Every building and weapon costs energy to build, and most cost energy to maintain, forcing you to constantly expand to new areas to build new collectors/reactors to beat creeper back by few tiles more until you can escape (CW1) or kill it for good (CW2/CW3)

That's it. But the way Creeper interacts with shape of the map means that there's a lot of strategy involved: where do you set up a defence? Can you cover the valley with collectors AND fortify it before creeper floods it? Do you go for tight grid of expensive but efficient and easily defensible reactors or for wide and redundant but hard to defend net of collectors? What combination of weapons will you use? How many blasters? Mortars? Sprayers? Maybe use Bombers, Strafers and Cargo planes to open another front on top of the hill instead of fighting uphill? How do you handle valley and mountain ranges?

Not to mention player-made maps of all sorts, including puzzles, "play as creepers" and tricky maps with lots of unexpected scripting.

Bonus highlight of the game is CRPL = Creeper Reverse Polish Language, a built-in scripting language giving map creators total control, even roguelike maps can be made.


I wholeheartedly recommend entire series, available from creator's page. Only latest instalment is on Steam.

20393630.review:
Creeper World 3 is an interesting variation on tower offense... You build towers to limit the spread of "the creep", something that spread like goo over all areas of the map like the Flood in Halo, except smaller. Weapons can limit them, but the only way to stop them on a world is to destroy the creeper emitter on the world by building a nullifier near it. However, nothing can survive in the creep... thus, you need to build a network of nodes to power the turrets, push back the creep, and eventually reach the emitter and shut it down. 

As you advance from world to world, system to system, creeps get... creepier. They get spore throwing towers (shoots a blob of creep anywhere on the map), but you get beam towers to defend against such. The defense "digitalis", which was supposed to destroy creep at the molecular level, had been subverted and now creates "pathways" to spread, but cannons and such can roll back such until you can destroy the digitalis emitter. Runner nodes generate small runners that can suicide, but you have "sniper" turrets against such. Then "glider" nodes with weapons defend against intruders near its paths. 

To counter those, you get better turrets. Mortar (ignores terrain), sniper turrets (mentioned before) that goes after runners and such but limited to line of sight, beam turrets against incoming spores (some are launched up to 4 at a time), sprayer to spray "anti-creep" (AC), bombers to drop larger qty of AC, strafer to slow a valley of creep, Guppy transport to move AC, energy, or ore around maps that has disconnected islands, Big Bertha cannon (takes out a big chunk of creep), better control nodes (longer range) and much more. 

Your command module along with collectors and reactors generates the power to power all the turrets. The trick is find control terrain to limit the creep to a section of the map, then roll it back section by section, by controlling key terrain much like all RTS games, without running out of power. 

You are some sort of warrior awakened after millenia of sleep, only to find desolation all over the galaxy, ruins everywhere, signs of combat and creep everywhere as well, shields and warp inhibitors did not save the worlds, but your strategy and deployment of units may. As you advance from world to world, star system to star system, your encounters gets worse and worse, enemies gets more and more complicated, but you get more and more toys to play with. 

While graphics are low-fi and 2D only it does not distract and in fact, keep the frame rate high and creep is sufficiently creepy enough. There are also visibility options to turn stuff on/off to help visualize the battle, with zoom. However, there is no edge scroll... You have to use WASD to scroll if you are zoomed in. 

It is different enough from regular tower defense to give you a good challenge, but it does get a bit boring after a while, or frustrating, as energy management is crucial, and there is no manual. Read beginner's guide on Steam before getting started. 

Verdict: Try. It is a very unusual RTS.

Graphics aren't stellar but they don't need to be. Som games need to look good and some don't. FPS and other action-oriented games all almost always more fun if they look better. Some games don't benefit much from a visual upgrade.

After playing more-recent shooters, it's really hard for me to play through (for example) Dark Forces. One of my favorite games of all time but it's such an eyesore that it's hard to play. They could maybe charge a few extra dollars if it looked like SC2 but then I'd complain that it wasn't worth the price.

20079468.review:
So basically, it's an RTS with a twist - the enemy is (mainly) some toxic slime and you need to get rid of whatever is spewing it out. There's a fluid mechanism that makes it possible for the slime to build up and spread out, which is kind of neat (e.g. if you're on top of a hill, the slime will take longer to reach you and it flows into cracks and valleys first).

So, the one player campaign begins nicely enough, you get introduced to units and game mechanics. The story is also interesting (and is mainly what kept me playing). However, it seems that on every mission there is always something new; a new unit or building you need to take into consideration that does one special thing which you need to take out some specific enemies. They're not exciting or add much to your strategy, except "to kill unit X you need unit Y". Which doesn't give you much choice of an attack strategy at all, except to build whatever is required to make it through the level.

And this is where the game fails the most - every level is a [i]grind[/i]. You quickly set up your defense perimeter, but once you manage that, it's slowly building up an attack force and inch by inch moving away enough slime to get to an "emitter", destroy that, and do the same for any other stuff you need to destroy. You know you'll make it, it just takes time and there aren't many surprises.

So, on top of not being very challenging or exciting except the first five minutes of every level, it takes between 45 minutes to over an hour to finish one. When you're finally done trudging through, you breathe out in relief - not satisfaction. Then you get annoyed because it has taken so damn long, and 90% of it was just waiting for things to happen.

So, to sum it up:

Yays:
* Interesting campaign story
* Fluid dynamics are nice

Nays:
* Levels are a grind
* Too specialized units make things more annoying than exciting
* Tactics are more or less the same every level
* Takes too long to finish a level
* Only exciting first couple of minutes on every level, after that it's just routine

I have played all three Creeper games, and loved them all. I liked the first better than the second, so when the third returned to the same style of gameplay, yet improved, buying it was a no-brainer.
I have played many hours on number 3 before it gor released on steam, and more after.

Most levels consist of establishing a beach head / base then beating back the unrelenting flow of creeper. When you reach their spawners, you can destroy them. When the last is gone, you win the map. Other levels have a master spawner that when killed destroys the others. Do you head straight for this one, or soften up the resistance first? The choice is yours.
Your main recource, energy, is often the most deciding factor.

Pro's:
- Nice long story arc.
- Endless ways to complete levels.
- Replayability to beat your previous best time.
- Level editor.
- Big community of custom levels.
- A ton of levels ship with it outside of the story arc.
- Programmable units (for custom levels).

Con's:
- Easy levels can get repetetive ("Just mopping up")
- Some of the smaler maps are insanely hard (could also be a Pro rather that a Con... ;-) )

Graphics / sound:
The game has simplistic graphics which is nice to look at, and more importantly, not so dazzling and cluttered as to confuse you. The soundtrack is good for the first few hours, but wheres a bit thin as the hours rack up. It can be muted in favour of what ever you like.


I give this game 10 / 10 , It is one of the few games I keep returning to for another couple of maps.

(PS! Creeper 1 and 2 are not avaliable on Steam. Visit knucklecracker.com if you are interested)

19559553.review:
Reviwing Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal.

Note: This is just my own opinion on the game, and I am but a regular gamer and not a professional games designer or critic of any sort. It is up to the reader to decide whether the statements found in this review is favorable or otherwise.

Introduction:
Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a RTS strategy game whose role of the player is to stop a corrupted fluid-like army from invading the galaxy. You command an army of automated buildings that shoot lots of stuff in order to prevent the fluid from spreading and destroying your base. These buildings are your bread and butter to fend off and destroy the fluid emmiters and win the game.

Pros:
1. The gameplay and its mechanics are really in-depth, and in each situation comes with a new strategy towards the game. Fend off even terrain with fast-firing cannons and low-land areas with strong long-ranged mortars, moving your base across space with, as well as weakening the enemy with ships and AC bombs. The campaign is designed for the players to explore each of these mechanics, as well as taking advantage of them in order to gain an advantage over the enemy.

2. There are tens of thousands of maps to play, both from the original official maps and custom-made maps from the workshop. Each map brings a different situation for the player to deal with. Besides that, creating a custom map is relatively simple and does not require any advanced form of coding or game designing knowledge.

3. The player is given a great amount of flexibility with various amounts of structures for them to build and control the game with, each being unique in their own way while complementing others.

4. The game kept me playing for longer than I've expected. Despite it being repetitive after some time, it was still pretty fun to play. An affordable game for a reasonable price.

5. When playing on a larger scale, the animations look kinda cool. It's always fun to watch your beloved "minions" go fight it out and do stuff.

Cons:
1. The soundtrack is too limited, repetitive and lacks randomization. I can memorize all of the battle songs after a few hours of play time.

2. The graphics are a little basic and simple, but this is not a big deal as the gameplay is much more significant in this situation.

3. The game acts sort of like a math question without much penalty Once you reach a stage where your buildings are self-sufficient in defending against the enemy, you can just sit back and don't do anything. From this point onwards, it will just be clearing out what's left of the enemy army, slowly but surely. Not much of a challenge up to that point.

4. To be honest, I was not very intrigued by the story, and I found myself skipping the storyline after playing the first few missions of the campaign. The method of presentation was tedious and boring.

Possible Improvements:
1. Ambience in the game would be nice. The songs do not have to be in a consecutive loop without end all of the time. Just play another song in a-minute-or-two intervals, something like Minecraft or Starcraft. That way, the player would appreciate the songs even more, and it brings a more exciting atmosphere into the game.

2. The presentation of story would easily be more attractive by using methods such as vocalized dialogs, pop-out characters, cutscenes (if budgetable) and subtitles.

3. The GUI and graphics could be improved.

Conclusion:
Creeper World 3: Art Eternal is a must-buy game for those who love tower defense and puzzle games. With an affordable price, the game is a pretty good choice in comparison to the more expsensive AAA games in the market. If not, the mechanics is something that makes the game worth exploring and trying out.

I would give this a 7.5/10.

Good game. I was quickly hooked on the campaign but then I got to Tormented Space which seemed impossible. I went to the prospector zone and it had many planets that were all too easy until I ran across Molreport which again was impossible. I have only seen a small fraction of the Arc Eternal universe so I don't know if there are going to be more challenging planets. I'm beginning to think that like most games that rely on user created maps, that there is a lot of tedium. You'll have to look hard to find challenging games once you finish the short campaign. 

There isn't a lot of variety in the buildings. If you zoom in close there isn't anything to see. There isn't much in the way of detailed tool tips. That's too bad because specific information could make a difference. I enjoyed terraforming my way into enemy territory but building shields is faster and less complicated. You just build millions of generators and then shield your way into the deep stuff and rip out the bad things by the roots. Bombers, straffers and guppies are there but they are rather tedious and much less effective. I didn't see people putting up lots of experience nodes to capture that might encourage you to level up your ore and AC carrying capacity in order to launch a big D day type invasion. 

I would highly recomend this game at the sale price especially if the professional types are going to build a longer campaign that is as delightful as their earlier campaign but this is not up there in quality like Mount and Blade or Kerbal Space Program. If their mission was to show those corporate types that they could do as good a job as any big studio, they didn't succeed. If Stardock is the MacDonalds of gaming then these guys are the Chinese takeout that opened on the corner with the crispy vegetables, delicious sauces and suspiciously slippery meat.

19302468.review:
This is 3rd in the Creeper series and it shows; 
headline feature from previous entries now casually sit in your tool box, and years of polish and good UI choices run through the experience.
This is the Creeper series at it's very best,

The core game is a pseudo tower-defense game, where the enemy "creeper" is modeled on thermodynamic movement (enemy propagates through the level like heat through a medium), and your personal infrastructure in modeled on packet switching.
The benefit of this is a game that's a very unique variant on the genre, and visually is wholly singular. 
Packets zip about your network as they beat back the horrors of living entropy!

Worth highlighting is the story; minimalist in a very impressive way. A few text back-and-forths at the start of a level are all you get, but they deliver fully on the feeling and weight of being trapped at the end of a dead universe; alone in the empty infinity but for your sole friend.

It would be nice if production values were a little higher. Sprites could be better; and the music though good, does get repetitive with it's few songs. Though the core experience is never deeply hurt by these weak points.

The game's single biggest flaw is in it's dynamics. If you survive the first few minutes of a fight it becomes a rather rote process of slowly expanding your territory, until 30-60 min later you've zapped the last enemy. 
There are frequent small decisions to make, but very few large ones. 
Despite the narrative weight of the-end-of-all-things and the cool high-energy packet switching & blasting of your little empire, the game ultimately feels like a casual experience. 
Mellowly click away, pruning your little bonsai death machine until you've won. 
A fine experience, but RTS and 4x fans will be yearning for more difficulty and substance.

Though some will wish it had more challenge, "Arc Eternal" is still an excellent little game! 
(And it's probably cheep by the time you read this.) 
Its uniqueness makes it well worth your time and money!

The actual review:

Story: This game takes place 5 billion years after CR2, that's all the story for now because i don't want to spoil things.
Gameplay: Every level except for the 2 systems leading to Prospector and Tormented zone, and the system which has Farbor in it introduces new mechanics. Such as Vapen which gives you your final command node, or Arca which gives you Thor. The gameplay is mainly build weapons to fight off various enemies and advance.The enemies are runners, spores, and the creeper. In addition to this you also have digitalists which can transport creeper over terrain instead of the creeper having to flow over. Many levels will introduce a new mechanic whether it's a permament enmy, a new tech, or a custom enemy, such as Ormos which has no emmiters, but creeper stuck in space and will come down once you land. Also on Ormos you get Terps whichcan terrraform the land. The terrian is in 10 levels. 1 being the lowest and 10 the highest, the previously mentioned digitalists can ignore this boundary and can jump terrain even if the emmiter strengh is at 3 (yes in the main campgain there are emmiters that emits 3 creeper every five seconds). You paint the terrian with whatever level you want it to be and the terps will slowly work on it. This can be sped up by a powerzone. The terps reqiure energy and the area they are terraforming cannot be covered with creeper. The powerzone enhanch all of your units abilities such as being able to make terps work faster and have a longer range or turning the motor into a fast firing, long range beast. The creeper is like CR1 so nothing to say there. However, the runners must be connected to digitalis to spawn and to survive. The runners will come out of runner nests and will stun your units, the best unit to kill them are snipers. The spores are like the ones in CR1 and CR2 they must be killed by beams and will drop a payload of creeper if not destroyed. The AE fields prevent your air units (guppys, bombers, and strafers) from flying over them. Your air units are guppys, bombers, and strafers. Guppys will transport  packets to your units such as AC, energy, or ore. Bombers use AC to spray down AC on an area and are the most powerful air unit. Strafers use energy and are essentually fighters. AC is short for anti-creeper and is gained from ore which comes from ore mines which can only be played on special spots or else you would win every mission too easily. There are 2 AC units, sprayers and bombers. Sprayers will spray AC that automatically fights creeper. It works like the AC from CR2 and it will protect your units if creeper hits them meaning that reactors will be safe if ac is on them. The main units are collecters, relays, reactors, blasters, motars, and nufflifiers. Collecters, will give you some energy and will expand you energy network, place these as far away from each other as possible since the energy production doesn't stack (they collect energy from an area like the ones from CR1). Reactors can be and should be placed in tight packs since they always give .4 energy, that can upgraded in the forge or using power nodes. Blasters have to have a line of sight and fire fast. Motars don't have to have a line of sight. Nuffelers can destory emmiters. The forge can upgrade things such as packet  speed, energy effifency, or weapon range (and yes move speed does apply to guppy's).  This review is getting very long and i covered most of the things i wanted to covers so now onto bugs.

If you bugs in this game record a video, upload it to youtube, and send me the link.

Oh and this game has maybe 30 story levels, 30-100 alpha levels (levels that were made in the alpha) a random generator, close to a thousand user-made maps some of which allow you to play as the creeper, and 2 areas with thousands of levels which add a new mechanic in addition to the regular stuff and an extra credits mission which turns it into a third person shooter so maybe 10 or infinity hours of content for you to play until you get bored

19168318.review: One of my favorite RTS games of all time. I can either rush or turtle to my hearts content.

19115767.review:
A Real Time Strategy game that emphasizes buildings over units. 

The third entry, I assume, in a series. I haven't played the other games, but was able to get into the story and gameplay with no issues. You are allowed to save at any time during a mission and in my experience the early story missions take roughly a half hour and the later more complex ones can take an hour to two, so if you can only spare a little bit of time per day, this game is very accomodating.

I normally enjoy RTS games for the interesting units and buildings over strategy, so I tend to spend more time building and upgrading than being any good at completing objectives. In this game, though, base building is the core. You are given the entire map to see, so you always know what is coming at you and what you need to prepare for. There are never sudden unexpected onslaughts of troops rush through your defenses. If you prefer to take your time in an RTS, this is a game that encourages it, with the exception of certain timed missions in the later story sections.

The main gameplay is set around starting a base and protecting yourself from the map-enveloping creeper and fighting it back enough that you can destroy the sources producing it. As you progress in the storyline you will be introduced slowly to new tech to help you and new threats from the creeper, such as missiles launched at you from towers. The game does a good job at teaching you how to use your new resources to deal with new problems and then challenging that new knowledge by mixing threats together. 

A complaint: Many, though not all, of the buildings can move themselves where you choose, which I don't believe the tutorial missions mentioned, or at least did not reinforce as well as the other gameplay mechanics. Since buildings consume energy and creeper that has reached them will damage them, it is very useful to know you can pick up and move rather than potentially kill your energy reserve with more weapons or helplessly watch a building get destroyed.

Potential negatives:
Once you've established your base and are ready to push the creeper back, the game tends to be fairly similar each mission, especially after you've gotten all the buildings available through the story missions.
There is one mission per planet and typically 1-4 planets per system. When it starts getting to an hour or two per mission. It can add up to a lengthy game with less variety than you might like.

18938585.review: I first saw this game, and thought it looked pretty stupid with it's color scheme, tiny, sporadic level design and seemingly "generic" style (I.E Strategy/Tower Defense-ish style building game just pumping out buildings).  Being open minded enough, and enjoying games like this anyways however, I threw it on my wish list, to revisit when it was on sale.  And boy was I glad I bought it, becoming one of my more quick favorites, moving up the list of a steam game I've purchased and actually played, beyond the title screen that is.  It's fast paced, with a pause button, and simple in terms of building order and/or layouts, but complex in the ways you can go about beating one level to the next.  It has a lot of advanced features, that aren't really necessary to win, but awesome when you figure out ways to utilize them (turning off building re-supply or disarming buildings temporarily).  The only downside I've found with this game so far, is that it's kind of challenging in a linear sort of way, meaning if you don't know what you are doing the first time a new building is introduced you can find yourself suddenly losing after playing a level for 30 minutes, which kinda sucks.  If you aren't sure of the buildings function or influence on the given level you sort of have to resort to trial and error a few times to figure out how to win.  However, that is the only flaw I have with the game so far, and it's a small one at that, as it is fun, challenging without being stupidly hard, and after a few times playing the visual style turns out to be perfectly fine.  Well worth the 15 bucks.

This is a weird little entry from out of nowhere, but it's pretty fun to play with.

At it's core it's a tower defense, but it's got a real bend to it. Instead of fighting discrete units you're battling an all-consuming goo that spreads rapidly across whole planets. As you can imagine, you're going to need quite a bit of firepower and miscellaneous technology to win.

What CW3:AE did add, however, was an incredibly entertaining campaign, a fully fleshed-out map editor, a fascinating overarching story, and an experience that, although relatable to Abraxis Stimulant, felt completely refreshing and fun. Build reactors, mortars, more reactors, do some upgrades, then more mortars, and more mortars and MORE mortars.

18808092.review:
Ignore the play time reported by Steam... I bought this game direct from the developer's website and played it for quite a while before activating it on Steam.  Plus, if you consider the first two games and the free versions on Kongregate, I've easily logged a hundred hours or more in the whole series.

I'm not a huge fan of tower defense or RTS, but this game combines the two genres in a way that is incredibly fun.  The basic plot is that a "grey-goo" type of substance, called the Creeper, has taken over the galaxy, and it's up to you to fight back.  You plop down a Command Node, build a few Collectors to generate energy, and try to keep from being overwhelmed until you can build up enough to go on the offensive.  However, there is enough variation in the game mechanics that each map presents a new challenge and a new puzzle to solve.

There is one map (anyone who's played the game long enough will know the one I'm talking about) that really ruins the fun and actually put me off the game for a long while.  Unlike the others where you can take your time and develop whatever strategy you want, this one is a timed mission and a pretty tough one at that.  So consider yourself warned...

But otherwise, an absolute joy to play and definitely a strong addition to your library.

18729866.review:
Ну, здравствуй, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/289440/]Периметр[/url]. Я скучал.

Надо сказать, что я не любитель жанра Tower Defense. Тупое упорство противников, топающих по дорожкам, сами дорожки, стандартный набор башен... И никакой возможности добраться до источника этой пакости. Поначалу это интересно, но, присутствуя в каждой TD, начинает надоедать. Чем хорош Creeper World? Да хотя бы тем, что он смог по-новому взглянуть на жанр, извратить его в хорошем смысле этого слова и практически полностью убрать вышеупомянутые проблемы. На мой взгляд он ближе к RTS, чем к TD, но для начала рассмотрим его как TD.

Больше всего, конечно, меня в TD отталкивали противники-лемминги, убивающие правдоподобность происходящего. Жгёшь их, давишь, плющишь, таращишь... А они всё топают и топают. Здесь в роли противника выступает Creeper - жидкость, которая течёт. Ей не важно, что её пытаются испарить, или ещё как-то уничтожить. Она просто течёт. Если перед ней будет ямка - она затечёт в неё. Если гора - растечётся вокруг. И точно так же, без ненависти и моральных терзаний нам нужно любыми средствами не позволить ей дотечь до нас. В некотором смысле получается симулятор сантехника - нужно прорваться сквозь разливающееся с каждой секундой море Creeper-а и заткнуть те дыры, из которых эта штука льётся.

Дорожки также были упразднены. В основном, карты представляют собой некий рельеф, по которому будет течь Creeper в полном соответствии с законами физики (ну, типа того). Он будет затекать в ямки, в которых его можно уничтожать большими порциями, огибать возвышенности, которые может создать и сам игрок, но если с ним ничего не делать - то рано или поздно уровень жидкости поднимется и до самых высоких точек на карте.

Что касается башен, большинство из них стандартны. Но есть и необычные экземпляры - например пушка, разливающая Anticreeper - такую же жидкость, но "дружелюбную" к нам. Все башни служат для вполне определённых целей и явственно отличаются друг от друга, в отличии от некоторых TD...

Ну а теперь взглянем на неё как на RTS.
Надо сказать, что некоторые элементы игры похожи на старый-добрый Периметр, поэтому я буду ссылаться на него.

Экономическая модель. В отличие от TD, где ресурсы обычно даются за уничтожение противников, здесь ресурсы производятся независимо. Добыча энергии схожа с Периметром - те же самые ядра, заодно служащие передатчиками и добывающие энергию с ровной поверхности. По ходу игры добавляются дорогие и эффективные реакторы, а также шахты.

Транспортная система отчасти также напоминает Периметр. По ней энергия и прочие ресурсы доставляются в места строительства и к требующим снабжения зданиям (в том числе к башням). Проводниками транспортных каналов служат ядра, или более эффективные (но не производящие энергию) передатчики. И если по каким-то причинам часть ваших зданий останется за пределами транспортной системы (передатчик затопило, ну или база куда-то улетела) - то работать эти здания достаточно быстро перестанут. С другой стороны, башни будут стрелять, пока у них не кончится боезапас, так что их можно использовать для вылазок в места без транспортной системы.

Говоря о башнях - они в большинстве своём могут передвигаться с места на место, тем самым больше напоминая юниты. Базу тоже можно передвигать, но в полёте она не будет производить энергию.

Терраформинг! Все любят терраформинг. И он тут есть. Ямки, горки, стенки, или ровная как блин поверхность - всё реально, если у вас будет достаточно энергии для прокорма прожорливых терраформеров.


Сравнения можно было бы и продолжать, но это раздует и без того длинный обзор. Я не буду расписывать вкусности типа Power Zones и карт с искажённой гравитацией, оставлю за кадром Споры и Digitalis, не стану вдаваться в подробности режимов PAC и SM... После прохождения сюжета игрок получает доступ к огромному количеству разнообразных карт, среди которых далеко не все обладают привычной механикой. Это игра с простой механикой, но способная увлечь вас очень, очень надолго.

Подводя итоги, тем, кто не играл, я рекомендую хотя бы скачать демку с сайта разработчика. Её наличие - это ещё один плюс в копилку достоинств игры. А тем, кто уже играл, я просто хотел бы напомнить о незаслуженно забытом Периметре - игре, которая неизменно вспоминается при игре в CW.

18403812.review:
One of the most fun and unique RTS/Tower defense games I've ever played. Basically, you're fighting a liquid. This liquid flows from higher elevation to lower elevation (like liquid does). There are emitters that pour this liquid out of them at specific intervals. You have several ways of corraling and destroying this liquid. Destroying thin liquid with laser turrets, deep liquid with mortars, or distant liquid with strafers. Corraling liquid with terraformers to lower or highten the terrain or shields that shove the liquid around. Or, even combinations of the two with anti-liquid that doesn't damage your towers and can destroy the bad liquid.

There are several play-modes too. 

The campaign starts you off with very little unlocked and very easy missions. As it progresses, you unlock more turrets, learning what each does with the missions getting harder and harder. Eventually, you have nearly everything and the missions have reached alarming difficulty, requiring epic strategy to beat, making each mission defeated a great accomplishment and very satisfying.

Colonial Space has a huge array of player created maps given ratings for each one with varying difficulties and extreme customization for each level.

Alpha Sector is filled with misisons created by alpha testers of the game.

Tormented Space and Prospector Zone have maps randomly generated by the engine.

This game is all about strategy, and nothing to do with luck. Love it.

I may be a little biased though, I've followed this series of games since the first. Creeper World was unique and amazing. Creeper World 2 was... okay, he took some aspects of the first one and made a different type of game that wasn't as well balanced nor built. But Creeper World 3 went back to the original gameplay of the first one, and he added many things to it, balanced it out, and made it a whole lot better.

18401325.review:
If you've played Creeper World before, know that this is an [i]excellent[/i] sequel. If you liked it before, you'll love this.

If not, then you're also in for a treat! CW is very, very good. People compare it to tower defence, but I usually describe it as a computer network fighting a liquid. The lines you see in the screenshots are the links between your units - if a unit becomes disconnected, it won't get resupplied and will eventually become defenceless. So, keeping supply lines going is incredibly important. The other thing is that your primary enemy is a corrosive purple liquid - it has no AI whatsoever, it just flows following the terrain. (Or sometimes it moves in other ways - the more scripted maps can have it behave in stranger ways.) The third thing is that terrain is everything. Perhaps the best defence in this game is just a really high wall... until the creeper overflows it!

This is a game about attacking, not defending however. Pushing forwards, often uphill, can be very tricky because most of your units can't attack upwards, and the creeper naturally flows down on top of you. Then you have to handle beach landings, and spore towers that will dump creeper right in your base, and runners that stun your units, and then all of these at the same time, uphill, with a time limit, along with all kinds of one-off scripted challenges too!

Later in the campaign you'll unlock units that can modify the terrain (slowly) and let you build a series of stepping stones above the creeper, or build walls to protect your home, or produce helpful "anti-creeper", or send supply ships to bridge between islands, or try to push the creeper away with force fields, or all sorts of other cool things. The fact that it's so freeform lets you find a style that's comfortable. I'm a big fan of terrain fiddling myself.

Seriously, this game has so many original ideas, and it's executed really well. Perhaps not the prettiest of games, but it's very clever, and it'll make [i]you[/i] feel clever when you finally conquer a map that's taken you hours. I can't recommend it highly enough.

18352498.review:
[b][i]Creeper World 3[/i] is a great game if you don't mind playing only single-player, which I think is a tough sell for modern day RTS games (or even tower defense, if you wanna classify it in that bin).[/b] It is certainly an interesting concept that works and there is alot of game to be had here, complete with online leaderboards to compete with friends/the world for best level-completion times. [i]While I enjoyed my time in [i]Creeper World 3[/i], I don't think I will  ever get my full moneys worth of fun.[/i]

The goal is to build and power a multitude of units to combat the creep (akin to the creep in [i]StarCraft[/i]). The main mechanic is based off of various geographic levels, or topography, where the creep gradually covers the entire surface of the playing map - or you fight it off and kill it at the source. That is the main enemy.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Really fresh concept that works well
+Tons of replayability and truckloads of units to build and strategies to master
+Great value for the price - that is if you don't mind playing a single player RTS for hours on end
+It is quite fun

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Leaderboards are not enough for me
-Having a relatively non-mobile enemy for every map can get dull (sometimes the creep has projectiles, etc., but in the end it is pretty much all the same)
-Interface needs worth, in example it would have been nice to have mouse-over hotkey help, etc.
-Graphics feel dated

[b]I can understand why this is one of the top rated RTS games on Steam, but and the end of the day, I need a bit more out of an RTS for any kind of sticking power.[/b] I think the enemy needs more complexity.

(Before edit, play time was 150-170 hours)

You get one very nice campain.
The game has an integrated map editor and you can play the custom maps made by other players.
There are also two areas with lots of auto-generated maps, some of them very difficult and few of them impossible.

I recomend the campain for those who like tower defense and strategy games.
I recomend the extremly difficult maps for those who like to discover alone how to improve and optimize.

I have not played yet any of the player made maps, so I can tell little about them. I know that you can use scripts and custom images when you create the maps so possibly the comunity maps might be interesting too. You can rate those too and I seen a thriving comunity there :)

Edit:
(08-Oct-2015) Play time: 209 hours

I made two maps, a normal map and one with scrips.

The programming language used in scrips is based on "reverse polish notation" concept: 
- you put the values into the stack and the operand afterward on top of them
- the operand will combine the top elements (these are consumed)
- the result is being placed back to the top of the stack

The concept is very different from normal programming languages. 
They say on the wiki that you do not have to be a programmer to learn this language.
I say this is true for any programming language. 
And after you learn it, you are a programmer. Not an experienced or profesional one, but a programmer nevertheless.

Regarding the maps: I made them for myself, as hard as possible. Some people do not like hard maps.
I will continue occasionally to make maps inbetween other games.
I avoid playing custom maps to avoid being influenced by their ideas.

17488350.review:
Creeper World 3 is very similar to Creeper World 1. 

For those who haven't played Creeper World 1:
You need to build and defend a little city from a relentless flow of blue goo whose physics behaves like water. You can vaporize it with lasers, blow it up with mortars, hit it with air strikes, and even terraform the landscape to trap it--for a while. The catch is that all of these things require energy, and you've got to find a balance between building up your energy supply while also building up your defenses. If you don't have enough of one or the other, the never-ending flow of creeper will slowly overwhelm your city. It's an excellent strategy game that combines defensive thinking and resource management.

For those who have played CW1:
This is mostly the same game, but with a story-mode and plenty of new levels. There's also a few new toys to play with, like ways to generate your own "anti-creeper," ways to terraform the terrain, and even ways to fly energy packets to remote areas that are not connected to your network. The creeper also has a few new tricks including "digitalis" which spreads faster and is harder to destroy but is limited to pre-defined paths, and "runners" which are little mobs that can temporarily disable your structures. 

I could knock the game for not being more innovative, but I liked CW1 enough that I thoroughly enjoyed having a similar experience again.

17315332.review:
tl;dr: I paid 2 euros for it. Got my money's worth but not much more than that.

One of the more innovative takes on the tower defense genre, but not without its flaws. 

There are no waves, just the relentless Creeper that keeps flooding the levels at a more or less steady rate. Meanwhile, the player builds all manner of defenses and the infrastructure to support it. It becomes a tug-of-ware between how much creeper is created and the player's ability to destroy it. Due to this mechanic, the hard part is usually the beginning, the containment of the creeper. Once that's done, the player would begin building more and more weapons to turn the tide in his favor. It gets a bit redundant, but luckily the devs have spiced things up a little with creative level design.

But that's just one way of playing the game. The other is to rush everything in minutes and ignore most of the depth the game has to offer. The worst part is that the tactic for rushing is pretty much always the same.

Having spent hours defeating single levels with the first method, I feel kind of cheated. I like the base building aspect in games, because it's rewarding to see the tide turn in your favor. But why would you do that if you can negate the tide before it rises up?

17283949.review:
This game has a thrilling story with a presentation that I absolutely love in strategy games, and it reminds me in this of one of my favorite RTS games, the first StarCraft. The gradual tech and story progression with each - sometimes long, sometimes difficult - mission, adapting to and overcoming the new challenge, is just very enjoyable for me. 

Now that I finished the campaign, though, I feel I have only scratched the game's surface. With all the user-created maps, and extra map packs the game provides, I am already returning for more challenges.

A criticism I'm reading in the negative reviews is how the game is the same grind all over again. Building up basic macro and defenses, and then progressing with micro as you upgrade your tech. For a game where every map is different, leaving a wide array of viable strategies and tactics to the player, I find this a very bad point. The SupCom-esque resource system, the focus on map control and relentless assault make this game very interesting, and even the initial 'always repeated' steps come in a personal flavor and depend on the map. 

The graphics may look abstract and weird in the screenshots, but they quickly make sense when playing the game. The terrain layers are also very consistent. And honestly, I found a salvo of Bertha shots' dispersed Creeper very satisfying to watch. There's few things like it.

If you're interested, watch some gameplay videos or just wait for a decent sale. I got it at -90% so sales do get decent! There's little room for disappointment at that price, and maybe it will cause you yourself to write a positive review in time.

In three sentences this game is one of the best strategy games i have played in a long time. Taking a genre that has seen little inovation in recent years and turning it on its head. Expect a fun and challenging game, with an interesting story and a truly staggering amount of dev and user created levels. If you want a new challenge in a game type you like, then this RTS is well worth a try.

A slightly more detailed opinion on the game is as follows.

Creeper World 3 may be the third in a series but this is the first I heard of it. I enjoyed this game so much i really want to play the other two. The gameplay is fresh and an easy to follow inovation of traditional RTS's. With a story mode that doubles as a tutorial, new tech is introduced at a steady and not overwhelmin pace, but not too slow either. Instead of mining traditional resources you mine energy(for the most part) which maily takes space, the more space you have the more possible energy you can get, using traditional looking turrets and air craft you have to defend against an insidious liquid like enemy that flows from a central point, trying to take over the level. From a gameplay perspective this game is well worth a go if your a strategy fan, and if you simply want a game that provides a challenge without being overly frustrating then this may well be a good game for you.

There are many features that will draw people from a leadership board, to simple but not old looking graphics, a different take on the RTS genre and of course the obscene amount of levels created by Devs and Users.

I certainly recomend this game as its deffinatly made it into my top favourate strategy games, and has just made it into my favourate games of all time. So what are you waiting for watch a video of the game and buy it. Its deffinatly worth the retail value, let alone a sale price

17158734.review:
I think Creeper World 3 catches a lot of people off guard because of the cheap price, low resolution graphics and understated appeal. It also gets called a Tower Defense game a lot, which does the unique strategic components a horrible injustice. Instead, Arc Eternal is a laid-back thinking mans' RTS with unprecedented play-more value and excels as a game you can sink some time into in the form of a well thought out and strictly controlled approach, or as a casual attack on a map every now and then. It's like Civilization V in the respect that you'll launch it for a quick 20 minute game and find yourself embroiled in the relentless depths of an alien planet fighting to make a foothold on a section of map on the 4th planet of your 3rd star system 6 hours later, wondering where the time went.

The amount of content in here is staggering, and the campaign provides such a good learning curve and introduction to the new structures and some possible strategies that can't be praised enough. There's also an engaging backstory in the main campaigns which help you feel isolated and alone while fighting the uncaring, unforgiving creep, and while the dialogue is cliche at times, it helps bolster the already engaging gameplay and add a little depth.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

The best part of this game is simply the gameplay. While the tower defense mechanics have been done to death and don't offer anything particularly insightful, the different natures of the two opposing forces here make for a level of adaptable strategy that you wont see in many games. The structures are all balanced and simple but effective additions like Terraforming and one-use items make for even more ways to play and even more things to spend time working on.

The sheer amount of content is the other great part of this world, and deserves praise.

* The first port of call is the Arc Eternal which acts as the campaign mode and teaches the player the basics and structures, and consists of 9 star systems for a total of approximately 50 levels.
* There's the Alpha Sector which includes many early maps and a ton made by the alpha and beta players.
* The Prospectors Zone features procedurally generated maps.
* There's Tormented Space for those seeking challenge which includes maps from hard to literally impossible.
* The Dial Map Device acts as a map generation tool and lets you play more specific maps.

[h1]Mistakes & Annoyances[/h1]

For many, the simple enemy A.I. is an issue here, and it can be argued that the very flat nature of the enemy intelligence makes for a somewhat bland approach. I'd counterargue and say that this game is more about finding solutions you like, and/or finding the optimal or most efficient route to victory and that the focus doesn't need to be on the creep.

* The difficulty curve isn't very smooth, and you can find yourself struggling way beyond what you'd expect in some of the later campaign missions, or struggling to overcome frustrating maps. There are also several outright impossible missions which nobody has yet been able to find a solution to.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

Arc Eternal comes priced at £10.99/14.99€/$14.99 and while it contains a huge amount of play time, including a main story of at least 15 hours, it's still probably slightly overpriced for most players when compared against competitors. It's one of those games which you'll either love or hate, and so playing the demos listed below, or the flash versions of the developers other titles before making a full priced purchase is recommended.

* If the huge amount of content included by default wasn't enough for you, there are a ton of user maps too with different types of play. There are [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=466266597]even [i]Play as Creeper[/i] style maps[/url].
* Some of the earlier titles are also [url=http://www.kongregate.com/search?q=creeper+world]available for free play in Flash on Kongregate[/url].
* There are demos of all 3 of the Creeper World games available on KnuckleCrackers' website which are much shorter.

17017418.review:
You can check this out in video form here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZS1dghQXlH0

Creeper World 3 Arc Eternal is a fluid time strategy game,
that is a game where you can pause and even speed up the time, just like in city builder games.

Creeper World 3 focuses heavily on base building. All buldings need to be connected to a resource network and many of the buildings can be moved in a way similar to the Terran buildings in StarCraft. 

The main enemy is the creeper, which is a fluid flowing out of emitters.
This fluid will flow downhill which is usually towards you. 
You cannot build in creeper and it destroys your buildings if it touches them.
The maps have 10 height levels and you can build terraformers to change the terrain gradually. This gives you tons of tactical options. The simplest example would be to build yourself a high wall as protection against the creeper. 
Beware that creeper levels accumulate and if you do not destroy some, it will flow over your precious walls.
You have various guns and mortars in your arsenal to destroy the creeper and you can even deploy your own anti-creeper, but this is just pushing back against the endless flow. 
To stop new creeper from forming, you need to push towards the emitter and build a special building, the nullifier, and protect it until it powers up enough to destroy the emitter.

There are other interesting foes and obstacles, which I will not spoil here. 
The bread and butter of the enemy is the creeper emitter. 

Most of the tension for me was usually in the early game, where I needed to stave off the creeper while building my resource economy and it's often about eeking out tiny little advantages until I could stably match the creeper. After that, the aggressive phase starts. 

There are dozens of interesting story missions with diverse leveldesigns where you need different strategies to win.

After beating the story missions, which took me about 30 hours!, you have a sheer endless supply of challenge maps, as well as tons of user generated maps. 

Though I find that the challenge maps aren't as diverse as the story maps, so once you find your dominant strategy, they tend to play out similarly. 

Creeper World 3 is also an excellent podcast game, since all relevant information is presented visually.

The game gets a clear purchase recommendation from me.
You can play the demo version beforehand, you can find that on the developer's website.

Creeper World 3 has a crazy high rating of 97% on Steam, which I think is because the Trailer shows you exactly what you can expect from the game.

16987800.review: I have personay put hundreds of hours into the three free flash based games, and I loved them all. I saw this game on steam and had to have it. Much to my delight, It has more content than all the previous games, COMBINED. This is a unique kind of tower defense (TD) game, with a much more organic feeling enemy than 'I just follow these paths regardless of the danger to my health.' That single change from the normal TD lets this game have so much more complex and involved levels. The towers range from simple towers like the blaster and mortar, to more complex ones such as the strafer and the XL cannon you get later in the campaign (Called Thors Hammer, if I recall correctly). You also have to manage your infastructure, otherwise your towers will stop working properly, and you WILL die (or at least lose a lot of ground). I love this game, and I hope you can at least give it a try. While this version has no demo, just look up the other Creeper World games online, those should suffice as a propper demo.

16874761.review:
A simple yet amazingly versatile concept: Build against goo.

In Creeper World 3 you take command of an automated base that gathers energy and ore and uses it to supply a diversity of weapons and utility tools, such as terraforming, to survive an seemingly endless onslaught of an oozy, purple substance called "Creeper".
Much like the Creeper that some of you know form Starcraft, this slow flood will damage your buildings.
In order to obtain, hold or destory a range of objectives, you will have to protect your base by clever build defences, until it provides enough energy to conquer and scrub-free new land. New land means new buildingspace and more energy and the circle repeats till victory.
The strong side of this strategy puzzle game is, that the way you expand is totally up to you.
Artillery and dropping additional bases is my recommended tactic.

It is not an easy game.
Players of Starcraft or similar micro/macro skill based RTS games will probably enjoy the level of APM that is needed to hunt the online highscores in this game.

Apart from being a challenging and fun strategy and puzzle game, Creeper World also has an own storyline.

A space captain and an ancient AI take on a seemingly hopeless battle against an alien race that teleports emitters of Creeper onto every planet which ever existed. As they try to understand the relentless hatred of their alien adversaries, the duo of lone survivors discovers a conspiracy that seems to be encoded into the very fabric of the universe itself.

It tends to stretch dialogues to create tention, which works but is a bit exhausting. Also the characters are aggressively unaware of the mysteries that surround them. But perhaps that's just me.
