16716588.review:
[b]On trouve peu d'information sur le studio Knuckle Cracker, ou plutôt sur l'unique développeur de Creeper World 3, si ce n'est qu'il avait déjà publié un premier et second opus. À l'origine, ce sont des vieux jeux flash obscurs qui traînaient sur le site du créateur. Mais y a des mecs obstinés parfois : malgré l'absence totale de visibilité le développeur a, au fur et à mesure des épisodes, peaufiné le concept de son jeu, pour au final sortir son troisième opus sur la plate-forme du gros (mais vénérable) Gabe Newell.[/b]


[h1]Cris et peurs (sur la ville).[/h1]

Mélange improbable entre STR et Tower Defense avec un fort accent pour le scoring, CW3 est un jeu plus complexe et intéressant qu'il en a l'air. Alors, bien sûr, graphiquement ça ne casse pas vraiment des briques, ni des parpaings, mais tout s'avère extrêmement lisible et c'est justement ce qui est important dans ce jeu.

Pour comprendre le principe du jeu, on va faire simple : le creeper est une sorte de fluide qui se répand éternellement, de façon continue et régulière. C'est l'ennemi éternel à stopper. Ce fluide, mortel pour toutes vos installations, doit être stoppé à l'aide de différents moyens. Que ça soit par des armes conventionnelles, qui détruisent le liquide qui approcherait de la ligne de mire de vos défenses, ou d'un module permettant de terraformer le terrain. En effet le terrain est en 3D et il est divisé en 10 couches superposées. Vous pouvez donc faire varier la hauteur du terrain pour stopper, du moins provisoirement, la progression du creeper. Vous pouvez vous barricader derrière des murs ou construire d'énormes fosses pour contenir le creeper. Mais sachez que cela est vain, le creeper continuera d'envoyer son liquide jusqu'à submerger vos défenses.
Pour vaincre celui-ci, vous devrez vous frayer un chemin jusqu'à ses émetteurs et les détruire, ces constructions sont responsables de l'émission du liquide.

Toute la force stratégique de SW3 réside dans l'établissement d'une stratégie de défense efficace, qui permettra de stopper la progression du creeper. C'est là tout l'aspect intéressant du titre. Le but est d'équilibrer la balance entre les deux forces respectives. Comme le fluide ne fait que fondre sur votre base de manière continue, si vous réussissez à le stopper, alors il sera ensuite possible de progresser, petit à petit, en récupérant chaque mètre carré de terrain, pour au final détruire les émetteurs.

Le jeu se compose donc en deux phases majeures : la défense qui permettra de stabiliser le front puis l'attaque, qui doit être le plus rapide possible. En effet, le jeu intègre une partie de scoring importante, qui nécessite de rusher le plus vite possible. C'est celui qui fait le meilleur temps qui obtient la place privilégiée du TOP 250 des meilleurs joueurs. Et je peux vous dire que ce n'est pas facile, vu la horde de fous furieux qui s'accrochent au high score.


[h1]Une optimisation au poil.[/h1]

Le jeu comporte des mécaniques finalement assez complexes, avec une gestion importante de l'énergie en flux tendu. Par conséquent, le but sera de gérer efficacement l'énergie : ne pas avoir de surplus, qui signifierait que votre stratégie n'est pas optimale et qu'il est possible d'optimiser votre conquête, mais pas non plus de pénurie, qui peut signifier bien souvent la mort pure et simple. Par ailleurs, le manque d'énergie provoque une baisse de l'approvisionnement en munition et en vitesse de construction des différents modules. Des tourelles qui tirent moins vite ne stopperont pas efficacement le creeper, qui envahira lentement, mais irrésistiblement, votre base.

La difficulté réside donc dans le fait de produire cette énergie, qui requiert des générateurs qui exploitent une zone donnée. Vous pouvez donc soit vous retrouver dans un cercle vertueux, soir un cercle vicieux. Je m'explique : dans le cas où vous ne produisez pas assez d'énergie et que le creeper gagne du terrain, la mort est quasi certaine puisque vous n'aurez pas la possibilité de produire assez d'énergie pour vous défendre. Dans le cas inverse où vous prenez petit à petit du terrain au creeper, vous aurez plus de zones pour produire de l'énergie, et donc la possibilité de construire des armes supplémentaires pour exterminer le liquide. Toute la difficulté sera alors de trouver le moyen d'obtenir une défense stable puis de contre-attaquer.

Comme le jeu pousse le joueur à rusher, il ne faudra ni être trop gourmand sur la conquête du territoire, ni être trop lent. Cela dit, la prudence est importante, mais la témérité est bien plus gratifiante.

Le gros défaut du titre réside en fait dans la seconde phase du jeu. Une fois qu'on a établi une stratégie pour faire face au creeper, il ne reste plus qu'à l'attaquer, et celui-ci n'a guère de moyen de se défendre (il possède cependant d'autres modules, comme les spores, sortent d'astéroïdes qu'il vous envoie périodiquement pour s'écraser sur vos installations, ou encore des robots qui désactivent temporairement vos modules). C'est donc une phase d'optimisation quasi mathématiques qui s'ouvre, dont le but est d'obtenir la victoire le plus rapidement possible. Cette seconde phase est, selon moi, moins intéressante.

Au final, la difficulté du titre est très variable. La campagne n'est pas difficile à terminer une fois les mécaniques du jeu comprises. Mais c'est bien plus compliqué d'obtenir le meilleur score possible et cela requiert une planification méthodique avec, en amont, tout un travail d'optimisation théorique de la défense puis de l'attaque.
En revanche, une fois la campagne terminée, le jeu s'ouvre à d'autres modes de jeux, dont le « tormented space », une galaxie gigantesque (des centaines de systèmes solaires contenant jusqu'à 14 planètes, donc niveau durée de vie vous en aurez pour l'éternité) aux niveaux parfois extrêmement durs qui ne pardonnent aucune erreur de votre part.

Ajoutez à cela une création procédurale des cartes (en dehors des maps faites avec les mimines du développeur) permettant d'avoir des niveaux infinis ainsi qu'un éditeur de carte très complet et une gestion rapide et efficace pour envoyer et télécharger les cartes d'autres joueurs. Ce qui nous donne au total un jeu au prix modique, mais à la durée de vie gigantesque.


[h1]Un gameplay novateur et efficace ? C'est possible ![/h1]

[b]En conclusion, Creeper World 3 est une excellente surprise parmi les jeux indés. Ce n'est pas prétentieux et pompeux comme une partie croissante de ce type de jeux, mais c'est en revanche diablement efficace et novateur. Comme quoi, c'est vraiment du côté des indépendants que l'on trouve les gameplays les plus improbables … et qui fonctionnent ![/b]}

16693668.review:
Creeper World is a tower defense with very unique gameplay and design. Unlike most tower defense games your enemy isn't a horde of monsters, but is instead a steadily expanding mass known as 'creeper'. Defeating the creeper isn't as simple as having strong towers - you have to know how to hold back the creeper while expanding your own area of influence, taking into account the the creeper will ooze in from multiple angles and will build up in areas of low elevation to eventually climb up onto higher ground. 

Your own building mechanics are quite interesting as well. Instead of having independent towers, you instead build a web-like network of resource gatherers, utility structures, and attacking towers. Managing this web can get quite tricky at times, because all resources must flow through a command center and take time to traverse the network. Done incorrectly you could end up building a tower but not being able to arm it in time to defend against the creeper. 

Also, while the creeper acts as a steadily growing mass, the player often ends up mirroring the creeper in many ways. Collectors - the primary resource generator - are most effective when spread out, forcing the player to expand their area of influence if they want more resources to spend. There are also many resource deposits around the map which must be contested, forcing the player to expand their area of influence even more. Aiding this playstyle is the fact that attacking towers can be respositioned, allowing you to leapfrog towers to slowly but steadily push the creeper back.

Overall the game is an excellent example of a unique twist on a genre and very polished gameplay. It's an extremely satisfying game to play and I highly recommend it to anyone who finds the concept interesting. Don't worry about not playing the previous games - they give more of the story, but this game is fully functional as a standalone experience.

I didn't like it. It's a puzzle game, basically, rather than a strategy one. Certainly not worth the money for me.

16670297.review:
So there you are, looking at this game like you're some kind of hot shot. "Oooh, look at me! I'm so badass! I could lift ten times my weight before breakfast!" Well, time for a wake-up call, sweetheart. With this simple, yet surprisingly hard to master little gem, you'll be doing war against the Creeper, an ever evolving, ever growing purple monstrosity, like the Smooze if it was genocidal and emotionless. You'll be taken back by how much strategy you have to implement to wage your war against the creeper. See, unlike your average RTS/tower defense, you can't just rush guys in and tire the enemy out. No, he'll be doing that to you. You have to cleverly work a way around using a multitude of offensive and defensive technologies. Standards like shields which protect you from the ever-increasing reach of the Creeper, to aerial units which provide ground support, and a landing pad for you to stage a beachhead against the amorphous beast. If you think you're Mr. Bigshot after hearing that, then prove it. Beat the creeper and send him to the reaper!

With that all said and done, I fully recommend this game. Especially when it took me about 15 hours to complete my first playthrough. I have to say that's not bad at all. And looking back, i even had tons of replay value checking out the other game modes, such as custom maps made by the developers, and those made by the community. Gotta really appreciate the simplicity of the game, which lends itself to such enjoyment.

EDIT: And after almost 100+ hours of enjoyment, I think I may be addicted.

EDIT2: After 400 hours, I ask you: Someone send help, I'm addicted to this damn game.

The economy system is incredibly similar to the likes of Supreme Commander. If you don't mind minimalistic graphics and love a good real time strategy that's really easy to pickup, but difficult to master, then Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is the game for you.

I hate to say it but Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal might have ruined me for all other Tower Defense-related games TT_TT The Tower Defense genre has become rigid and formulaic over the years, the core gameplay has become ridiculously arbitrary. CW3 has re-introduced a sense of urgency to the core gameplay of the genre, in a fresh new way. Players of CW3 are only limited by their own creativity; I've barely scratch the surface of the single player campaign and I have already developed my very own unique way of strategizing and dealing with the Creeper.

The depth of the core gameplay is intelligently designed and built, and the soundtrack is beautiful and albeit repetive, fits perfectly with the non-stop strategizing action. 

How will you approach the existential problem that is the Creeper? Stretch far and thin for some quick advantages, or build up a defense to nurture an unrelenting force against the ever-growing blue goop? You decide.

5/5 Thumb up and yes, yes, yes.

16511152.review:
The third game in the fantastic creeper world series. It takes the gameplay of the original, and builds on it; interestingly, it gives you all of your old toys pretty quickly. The anti-creeper from the sequel makes a return, and works quite well. The level design was decent, although there were times when I felt it could've used work, and I rarely found it necessary to use more than one control node, with the exception of the timed missions.

The story was the weakest part, having reduced the cast to just two members: Abraxis and his ship's AI. There's some good world building, but I think it could've been greatly expanded upon, and the twist ending was really unexpected, and felt out of place. I'm not fond of stories that retcon their own history. If you want a great story, I'd recommend playing the original, which is still the best in this regard.

I was honestly hoping for a longer experience overall, but there is replay value in the form of custom community maps (still haven't tried it yet), as well as a random map generator which need to be unlocked through the campaign. Something I'd love to see is a massive map, spanning several screens in size, with complex terrain and hidden secrets buried around the map; the only time you excavate anything in game is during the last level.

On the whole, fans of the genre will enjoy this, just don't expect any literary awards. 8/10.

This game is absolute perfection. I've played Creeper World 1 & 2. I wasn't exactly sure what to expect coming into this, and I was a little sketchy paying a few bucks for it.

16441214.review:
Argh...its like crack, I tell you now - stay away!

In all seriousness, its very engaging in many ways. To me, it is the logistics of war, abstracted into a fight against the "grey goo" of science fiction. You begin by dropping on-planet, setting up energy collectors and ore mines, and trying to stay one step ahead of the goo by running relay lines (think high-voltage lines) to power the various weapon systems you'll need to fight it. Cannons, mortars, sprayers, and other tools are at your disposal. Interestingly, you are able to reposition them as the situation on the ground changes. From there, it is a systematic war of resources and logistics to reach the Emitters that produce the Creeper/Goo. You then build a nullifier which charges up and fires a high-powered beam into the emitter, destroying it.

I'll be the first to admit I haven't made it far yet. Two hours in, and several missions in the story mode. I love every useful goodie I find on planets and put to use as I go. I'm sure there are many others out there to find. Icing on the cake to me. It's fun without being overly complex, and very easy to get caught up in the deadly "just one more turn" syndrome.

For two bucks, hours of fun. Grab it and give it a try...if you dare! *Muahahahah!*

16438624.review:
Review written after 10 hours of play.  Summary, well executed, fun and satisfying game but turn the volume down. 

 Interesting RTS that doesn't follow the usual formula.  You are fighting against a rising liquid tide and have to plug your defenses then expand outward.  Has a simple yet effective art style that conveys all the information you need.  Playstyle is reminiscent of tower defense but more immediate, at the same time levels can often feel like a puzzle.  This combination means finishing a level is usually very satisfying.  The game does an excellent job of gradually introducing the mechanics and units and the levels where they are introduced do a good job of teaching you how to use them effectively without holding your hand.  The creep behaves intuitively leading to emergent strategies that the game never outright tells you about but make perfect sense, particularly as regards the terraforiming.  You can make walls and trenches to control the flow of the creep, or push back an area then build walls around it to expand into a large pool.  So far the levels have been varied enough that each new level has made me think 'ah interesting, how am I going to deal with this?'  

  About the only negative I've found is that the sound design.  Weapon sound effects can be very repetitive, especially when you are in the late stages of a level and have many mortars and strafers firing at once.  Also the music while by no means bad is very penetrating and booming and combined with the sound effects can be extremely irritating for other people in the house who aren't playing the game.   Easily sorted by turning the volume down and the games other qualities make this a relatively minor grumble.

16387134.review:
Hello, guys!

I really can't even how good this game is. I've played CW2 before, so I didn't hesitate to buy this game as soon as I've noticed it.

What is CW all about? It's an interesting strategy, where you don't fight against enemy units similar to yours, but massive amounts of creeping blue goo. So it feels a little bit like tower defence, but really innovative one.

The in-game economy system is quite simmilar to one from Supreme Commander (which I loved too!) and it's based more on flow of the resources than stockpiling them. This approach forces costant action, which is nice.

So, does concept still feels to You boring? Fear not, as so far every single map is quite diverse and suprises me with something new (I've completed about 30% of game, and CW2 which was quite brilliant too!). Your enemy sometimes spawns various units too, and the goo doesn't always act like it's expected to. 

The game has its own plot, which is not that plain. There are no cosmic civilisations fighting against each other. There's no war, humanity lost against creeper long ago. You've been asleep for 5 billion years. All you can do is crawling through ruins of ceased race of humans, and try to make sense of what happened. Why do I even mention history in such simple game? Honestly, because at this point I am simply curious how will this story end.

The only 2 downsides I've noticed are:
-crappy, plain graphics. I don't think it matters though, as this simpleness comes in one package with perfect gameplay and practical interface.
-lack of multiplayer. Seriously, guys, I don't care, add it somehow!

What do I say at the end? Mabye I'll describe my general feel about it. This game feels like the best flash game ever, but with large campagin and saving and stuff. Buy it. Do it. I don't think anyone would regret doing it, except if it makes him fail his exams or sth.

So far i'm loving this game, i picked it up during the steam sales for like 2 bucks but its worth so much more than that. 

The gameplay is a interesting mix of towerdefence\survival\rts similar to infested planet but controlling structures instead of a moving team, if you enjoyed infested planet i'd highly recommend this. The approaching doom of the creeper goo gives you a survival feeling i haven’t seen many games be able to recreate.

While i'm a firm advocate of "gameplay before graphics", i can’t help but feel that this game deserves better graphics, not to say that the gameplay is effected, but the gameplay is so nicely polished it would be great to see graphics that match the high level of gameplay, Its ovbious that the creator is probbly more comfortable with programming (I'm sorry if you're not!) which isnt nessisarily a bad thing because the gameplay makes up for it massivly, but the graphics in their current state are kind of plain and the looming doom of the creeper sludge or whatever it is, isn’t quite captured as well in its current opaque single colour state. Regardless I’ve been enjoying the hell out of the game

Lastly, i would love to see more types of items to defend with, aside from using the anticreeper goo turrets and the jets, i found the game mostly revolved around the standard turrets and mortars, with some specialty units thrown in that are only situational, they're fun but more variation would be nice. Also the block building thing is overpowered as hell, really needs some sorta finite resorce to stop you from just cheezing it and building a 10 high bridge all the way to the spawners, i'd like to see it cost more or be limited somehow because it makes defending way too easy, maybe combine it with the ore production so it costs a bit more, I’m a bit of a turtle style builder but this gives you way too much control. 

But yeah buy this game!!

16352704.review:
Allowing you to choose and even build your own maps, this is a somewhat sandbox mode TD at it's very finest.
Yes there are some timed story levels, my only complaint.

Gameplay wise, there are so many ways to approach a problem that often you'll find yourself in minecraft mode.
With terraforming, you can raise and lower terrain, and this map change dynamic can make a play totally unique.
From digging a pre-emptive pit for the creep to go into and make good use of the mortar, making a defensive wall, to even just creating the new high ground - you're going to be able to say screw it to most conventional strategies and play your own way.

Tips for simple success: 
-Do not leave snipers alone, they can still be stunned/destroyed.
-Shields should be saved for advanced strategies, most of the time they're just a major power drain.
-Soak the space behind your defensive lines with anticreeper, holds it at bay long enough to salvage a screwup
-Reactors do NOT connect to other reactors - you still need nodes in clusters

The rest, wing it, you'll figure it out.

This is one very addictive game!
I fully recommend it!

To sum up what you do in this game is you fend of creepers, which advance across the map as a fluid. Some maps also feature spores and other special units to mix up the challenge.
Your goal varies, sometimes it is to wipe out the nodes that spawn the creeper. Sometimes you just need to unlock a shield bubble(which usually is at the far end of where you can land).

To help you out with this you got different types of turrets and some units you can build up.
In order to win you can usually choose to go either turtle mode or just rush. Some maps force you to play extra aggressively, otherwise you will be overrun if you try to turtle.
Most importantly is to keep that production going so you can support whatevery style you choose.

Creeper World 3 is, by far, the most unique game to be found in the Tower Defense genre. Manage supply lines and fueling costs as you take the fight to the enemy; balancing defense with offense. The enemy in this case is an ever-pooling substance which enroaches on the planet. Perfectly simulated, the entity overflows and spills out into the environment in a believable manner. It's up to you to repel and, eventually, destroy it at the source. 

Pros: 
+ Great difficulty curve. Not too hard, not too easy. 
+ Brilliant concept.
+ Managing supply and energy costs is fluid and satisfying.
+ Presentation is simple and effective; height/depth is easy to see at a glance.

Cons:
- Lack of tooltips can lead to confusion.
- Where did the last 3 hours of my life go?

16342885.review:
Quite the addictive Tower Defense esque game. I am writing tower defense esque, because you are not exactly fighting waves of enemies, but instead you are fighting waves of goo. The goo is generated by one or more spawner on a topographic map. The spawner acts as well for the liquid goo that is starting to slowly spread from its origin and you are tasked with destroying the spawner.

In order to destroy the spawner you have to build an infrastructure that can fuel and provide your military forces (Towers) the necessary energy to stem the tide of the goo. You start from your own base/spaceship and extend from there, building collectors and relay stations in order to gather and transport energy to the guns. The guns once build have to be provided with energy in order to shoot. If the goo touches the base of the installation, the installation gets destroyed.

As mentioned before, you are fighting on a tophographic map, which means every map has several layers and you can for example use the high advantage of a plateau in order to attack the goo beneath it. The goo, behaving like a liquid has to fill the entire level, before it can advance in height, which can be used by the player via terraforming the level.

A quite addicting little game. Although, little might be a bit confusing. There seem to be at least 250 levels in the game, and for the hardcore, there are time attack leaderboards.

This game takes the idea of a Tower Defense game, and completely reworks it::

16335043.review:
Tower Defence с уникальным геймплеем. 

В целом геймплей можно поделить на 3 стадии:
1. В самом начале, успевая кое-как понатыкать ресурсные башни, назревает один парадоксальный вопрос: строить реакторы для подъема энергетики или уйти в глухую оборону, построив побольше турелей. Обычно неверный выбор приводит к тому что когда "крипота" наползает на ваши позиции, вашим турелям не будет хватать энергии чтобы дать хоть какой-то отпор... рестарт и опять все сначала.
2. Когда уже энергии хватает чтобы строить больше энерго-генераторов, при этом ресурсов хватает на поддержание обороны. Опять становится выбор: долго и нудно заниматься терраформированием (в игре есть разность высот, которую можно "подстраивать" под себя с помощью терраформеров), буквально отвоевывая по квадрату у "крипоты", медленно и верно продвигаясь к вражеским источникам или избрав более скоростной вариант, построить побольше мортир и пытаться штурмовать высоты количеством.
3. Когда энергии уже становится некуда девать, а свежезахваченные территории мигом обрастают генераторами, становится актуальным вопрос о постройке воздушного флота, эдак кораблей на 50-100. На этой стадии вы просто получаете эстетическое удовольствие от "проделанной вами работы" и неспешно завершаете карту.

В среднем на прохождение одной карты уходит от 30 минут до 2-х часов (базовые обучающие карты в расчет не идут). 
Общее количество карт захватывает дух: более 300, если вам и этого мало, то есть возможность создавать и делиться собственными картами.

Рейтинг игры: 10 слоупоков из 10

16322662.review:
9/10, would highly recommend.

I remember playing this game many years ago, loving the fresh take on the typical flash-based TD genre. Being the third iteration of the game, it returns to it's roots after the admittedly mediocre sequel.
With classic gameplay from the first, a new campaign, new features and enemies, and a gazillion new user-created and randomly generated levels to play, this game is almost infinitely replayable.

I only have one issue with the game: Difficulty.
You are expected to play agressively and take risks against the already agressive creeper; I find this quite difficult as a player who likes to take things slow and cautiously, but that's just me.

Overall it's an amazing game and a fresh take on an over-used genre.

PS. If you enjoyed the sandbox TD style of this game, you should check out 'Harvest: Massive Encounter', another favourite of mine.

I bought this awhile back after being a big fan of Creeper World 1 & 2, and the developer managed to top himself with CW 3. The game is addicting and has amazing replay value, I love jumping into it to to kill some time with a casual game, and the system requirements aren't too bad.

Far and away my favorite feature is the new "Colonial Space", which allows you to download User-Created maps. More to the point the game supports custom scripts in mods, which means that dedicated users have been able to add new game mechanics to their custom maps to implement new superweapons, enemies, or even to allow you to play as the creeper! I haven't even finished the campaign, I just endlessly play custom maps. My only complaint is you're required to complete the game's tutorial missions in the campaign before you can play custom maps.

As a side note, I originally bought this game when it was standalone, and got a free Steam key when it became available on Steam, so kudos to Knuckle Cracker for that.

15940956.review:
Vynikající hra s unikátním konceptem

Klady:
- Opravdu unikátní koncept. Nebojujete proti nepříteli který by na vás posílal hory jednotek. Bojujete s nepřítelem který (většinou) respektuje fyzikální zákony a snaží se vás rozdrtit pouhou hrubou silou.
- Skvělé pokračování série. Hra je v top-down pohledu, stejně tak jako původní creeper world. Nepřítel respektuje terén, který můžete modifikovat terraformací. Některé mapy mají také speciální funkce (zdi, gravitační pole, atd.)
- Dobrá kampaň s pěkným příbehem a propracovanými mapami. Pokud máte ostatní hry ze série creeper world doporučuji si je zahrát před touto, není to nutnost ale pomůže to znát ten příbeh, hlavně z jedničky.
- DMD což je generátor náhodných map umožňuje téměř nekonečné množství herního času. Ve hře je opravdu hromada map.
- Nebaví vás generované mapy? Ve hře je tzv. Colonial Space, což je možnost stahovat si mapy od jiných hráčů. Díky skriptování které hra nativně podporuje jsou některé mapy velice propracované. Můžete například obrátit role (a hrát za creep, tu modrou "břečku" se kterou normálně bojujete), nebo bojovat s nepřítelem který také staví budovy jako vy.

Zápory:
- I výkonnější počítače mohou mít na velkých mapách s větším počtem jednotek a staveb trochu problémy s výkonem.

CELKEM
94/100 - Téměř perfektní hra která skvěle zakončuje celou sérii.

15456912.review:
I've bought and played all variants of Creeper World, and this is the best one yet.

It's very good at scratching the strategy, RTS, tower-defense itch.

However, the nature of the enemy in most levels, essentially a corrosive liquid, combined with periodic balistic strikes, means that once you have built up your initial defense, you are effectively safe and need only expand your defensive line until you eliminate enemy towers/units. (Yes, I know there are other enemy-types besides the two mentioned above, but none that show up mid-game or late-game, to create dynamic havoc in your carefully laid plans.)

There IS the concept of pre-existing barriers that corrode, giving a timed threat-release, but these are rarely employed to anything like the full potential of providing a mid-game threat. Even if they did, there is nothing that provides a late-game threat or reversal of fortunes, no increasing flood of more powerful foes, etc. There is no ramping up of the initial threat which might turn the tide if you don't deploy for it. Really, the only way to lose a game at the mid-point or toward the end is user error, like uncovering a flank with anti-missle defenses and having an attack get through to the rear. Even then, if it doesn't cut off significant supply lines, which can easily be made redundant, then the front-line may not be affected at all by the misfortune.

But then... you can download fiendish levels that are user-made to solve that problem to a degree.

8/10 (or relatively speaking, as fun and playable as any game in the Tower Defense genre available on Steam, if not more-so)

Ta gra to właściwie nie tyle Tower Defense co jej odwrócenie. Jedynie na początku gracz musi szybko zbudować bazę i systemy obronne, następnie przechodzi się do kontrataku.

Sama gra polega na zajęciu całej mapy i usunięciu z niej creeperów, w tym celu należy zniszczyć wszystkie wrogie instalacje. Czasem trzeba też zdobyć jakiś obiekt, na przykład klucz, dzięki któremu fabuła posuwa się do przodu, ale to wykonuje się niejako przy okazji. Nie ma tu sztucznej inteligencji, z którą należy walczyć, są po prostu złożone, ciekawe i często skomplikowane mapy przygotowane przez autorów gry.
Wachlarz oferowanych strategii jest bardzo szeroki, nie ma jedynej słusznej drogi, dzięki której można osiągnąć zwycięstwo. Grę w każdym momencie można zatrzymać aby przyjrzeć się sytuacji na mapie, samą mapę można dowolnie oddalać lub przybliżać. 
Interfejs jest prosty, muzyka przyjemna, grafika dwuwymiarowa, dzięki czemu gra nie wymaga mocnego komputera, zajmuje niewiele miejsca na dysku i szybko się uruchamia. Jest to więc świetna strategia dla osób, które mają słabego laptopa.
Map przygotowanych przez twórców jest multum, dodatkowo dostępne są też mapy stworzone przez innych graczy oraz kreator map. 

Polecam tę grę każdemu kto przede wszystkim szuka rozrywki nastawionej na myślenie i planowanie. Dodatkowo warto przed zakupem zagrać w darmową przeglądarkową wersję gry. Jest ona co prawda uproszczona, ale pozwala zapoznać się z mechanizmem i z działaniem gry.

Samą grę mam na komputerze z systemem Ubuntu, chodzi bez żadnych problemów.

The scripting engine incorporated into Creeper World 3 by virgilw is very encompassing and allows me a lot of freedom to create new playstyles and new maps. There is a very engaged community with a well used wiki documenting all sorts of use-cases.

15067820.review:
In my opinion, Creeper World 3 is more carefully crafted and more well-made than most big-budget games out there today, it truly is a show of how it isn't the budget that matters, it is simply how the game ends up being upon release.

How was it on release? It was pretty good, having had it about a month after it was released on the Knucklecraker site, it was later released on Steam, and due to the Developer beign a really awesome person, Virgil allowed all previous owners of the game, to get a free steam key, since they'd already bought the game.

So okay, I'm keepnig this one short.

The game is basically a Tower Defense/Real-Time Strategy hybrid, where the enemy is not identical to you in any possible form. Your enemy is (as the store page itself says) a fluid-like substance that flows over the transformable terrain. This substance acts exactly like water, only if it touches your stuff, it either outright destroys it immediately (non weapon/titan units) or it slowly melts away at it (Weapons and titans).
The substance flows from emitters, which you need to fight towards, and destroy them using Nullifiers, doing this as you go from world to world, saving them all from the Blue Tide named Creeper.

Pros:
- The Story is well-written honestly, keeping you guessing, even after you've beaten the story.
- Unlike previous entries, you can use Titans, which are like superweapons, and they are awesome!
- Also unlike previous entires, there are three endings insted of only one.
- Each Story mission has many ways of beating it, there are those "Per map strategy that always wins" but no single strategy will get you a victory on every map.
- The Environment actually means something in the game, allowing you to create fortresses for defense using terraforming, or for offense to get an easier shot at something, or even boxing in an emmitter.
- The Soundtrack is by far the best I've ever fonud in the game. It perfectly fits the game's underlying post-apocalyptic setting set in the far future.
- There are no bugs that are atleast in-game. It's never crashed, it's never frozen without external conflicts, it doesn't even have glitches.
- You can make the Creeper any color if blue doesn't work. Red, Black, White, Purple... if it exists as a color, you can do it pretty much. Also works for anti-creeper too.
- Literally thousands of levels to play after the story, with levels made by testers and part of the dev team like MadMag, the artist behind the game, or Virgil, all made with the game's own random map generator, the DMD, Dial Map Device.
- Has the most impossible level ever put on a strategy game, Jovincoting, a map so hard, absolutely nobody has ever beaten it. This game has technically been out for about a couple years now. Or almost.
- Strategy mostly consists of neat tricks you pick up along the way than actual builds as following a build will slow you down in almost every possible case, due to how maps are all different.
- The Game has a map editor with it's own scripting language, using it can allow you to change the game form what it is, to a top down shooter (Credits mission), or even a game where you play as the creeper against AI-controlled enemy command nodes.

Cons
- The map selection music will often content ID youtube videos showing it.
- I literally cannot think of anymore Cons. I've been trying to for the last two days.

All of this and even more is only 17 dollars CDN, probly 15 US. Just get it, this game is basically one of the best, most underappreciated titles on the market today. A must buy for anyone who likes a good strategy game.

14835517.review:
[h1]

Creeper World 3 is quite a unique game, it feels like a tower defense game mixed with real-time-strategy elements.

Like in most other RTS games, you have to build a base, though here it is more like a 'power grid', which is essential to power all your defensive and offensive structures. The main difference here though, is the enemy. Instead of tanks, humans or monsters, you have a lava like liquid, that slowly creeps its way to your base and tries to 'fill' the entire map.

It's called 'The Creeper'. I know, it sounds like the name of a cheap 60s horror movie, but it's not.

Anyways, most of the time you'll build turrets, mortars, jet fighters and bombers to defend yourself from The Creeper. But usually that's not enough. You also have the option to 'terraform' the environment. That way you can either dig trenches, or, which is a lot more effective, raise the terrain to wall off your base.

The whole process is quite a lot of fun, especially when you unlock things like the Bertha, which is a giant cannon, or the Thor, which is a giant spaceship with multiple turrets that rains death from above.

The thing I like the most about Creeper World 3 is that you can play whatever way you like. This might be the slow and defensive way, or the fast and offensive way. This is quite important if you care about getting in the top 10 list of each map. These lists are primarily sorted by how much time it took you to complete the map, though to be honest, you'll have a hard time beating the best times, since they're usually around 20 to 30 seconds for each map. This is especially frustrating because I doubt those times are legit most of the time.

All in all though, Creeper World 3 features a huge amount of content, which is good if you like getting your money worth. It's also bad if you want to 100% this game, because judging by the amount of levels, it might take you hundreds of hours to do so.

There's also the fact that you can make your own maps, and play other players maps right inside the game. This gives Creper World 3 almost infinitive content, though some player created levels might be too easy, or even impossible to beat.

Conclusion: Amazing game with an enormous amount of re-playability, easily worth the full price if you're a fan of tower-defense/RTS type of games.

[/h1]

14814646.review:
Creeper World 3 is an absolutely brilliant game of logistics and equilibrium, where the goal is to fight a sea of fluid. Everything comes down to building networks of weapons, shields, and other devices to slowly push forward against the rising tide. Full map terraforming, a wide variety of weapons and upgrades, movable towers, artillery, shields, and aircraft are all tools at your disposal. The story campaign has a wide and clever variety of mission types and goals, and an interesting "big idea" sci-fi story line reminiscent of Arther C. Clarke is the icing on the cake here. The random mission generator, huge variety of additional non-story missions, and sizable community map selection ensure you'll never run out of new challenges. A generally slow pace, as well as full pause-and-issue functionality, ensures that you can play as methodically as you like. Fair warning, there is one timed mission in the campaign (Farbor), but after a replay or two you'll be able to beat the 35 minute timer without too much difficulty. Being smart is always vastly more important than being fast in this game.

Any fan of strategy, especially logistics-heavy strategy, would do well to check this one out. Highly recommended.

14793680.review:
i pondered the question of whether this game gets my recommendation or not for some time. this is how i broke it down.

this game is a 2D top down tower defence game, like the literally billions of games out there. the thing is: a) does anything make this game stand out from the crowd and b) is it fun?

the story is told in text boxes between you and your onboard AI, in this day and age i find this is kinda lazy and must admit some of the early story i just ignored, if i wanted to read the story constantly id play Final Fantasy 7 or earlier.

obviously as the game progresses you get an array of different weapons of which to fight the Creeper...or purple gunk/liquid as i like to refer to it.
the "enemy" just kinda oozes over the map at different rates depending on the map level, so it becomes a balance of power, expansion and defence,  missions can be won or lost by over reaching too soon or being impatient when waiting for power cores to be built, and power is essential.
the game starts out quite easy but then becomes challenging in no time at all, indeed the game kicks you in the butt for any lapses of concentration.

the graphics are really quite basic and the unit design is awful, indeed when you have straffers, bombers and then try to move stuff it all gets messy quite quickly. the maps can be anything from huge to tiny bringing their own challenges and/or rewards.

the best weapon in game has to be the sprayer, it can create that all important safe zone to defend whilst you consolodate your base, However, they need Ore for ammo and that can be a massive issue on some maps. like i previously mentioned you can move your turrets and base around which actually is qute a fun gimic as it lets you make a rolling advance on the enemy or plug any gaps without waiting for new units.

later maps allow you to build a forge for turret upgrades that affects turrets instantly (no need for further upgrade time) and Bertha guns that basically can wipe out your upgrade points in 1 shot for minimal return given the creeper can at times spawn super fast (the bertha fire Aether that you need for upgrades)

(Spoiler)  and then on the last mission you get the Titan, a space ship that can shoot rockets etc but is pretty useless on the whole but essential for the last mission.

all in all the game is challenging, and will punish the unprepared quite early, but saying that there is a map creator and a massive online community that designs maps for you to try, it also has a prospector zone whereby you can fight in over 100 maps for stuff or play other players maps in the Alpha zone so even after the story missions theres still hundreds of maps to play. 

a massive gripe i have with the game is the music, 1 track on a constant loop....wouldnt be so bad but it lasts like 5 mins and some maps can take over an hour to beat so you have to listen to it over and over again just to start all over again on the next map, another gripe is the ability to store your score per map online after each level, however the peeps at the top of the leader bored somehow managed to beat the map in like 35 seconds to score 9k points, yeah right...

so ok for the fact the online community is there and theres an almost endless ability to play the different maps i'll give it a thumbs up. However i personally got bored quite quickly, the story is barely believable, the music drove me to distraction and theres no veriety really, another map, another ooze producing blob that needs to die rinse and repeat but then again thats the formula for every Tower defence game out there. the ability to move turrets is great but i dont know     if they pioneered this gimic.

14581285.review:
TL;DR : Très sympa, addictif, un très bon achat, vaut largement son pris, même à plein tarif (alors en promo, c'est encore mieux).

Version longue : 

Je ne connaissais pas la licence, je ne peux donc pas comparer ce volet à ceux qui l'ont précédé. Acheté en promo (comme toujours), je petit jeu ne m'a pas déçu, et m'a même agréablement surpris. C'est un genre de mix entre tower defense et STR, avec des petits bouts de puzzle game (mais franchement, cette description ne fait pas justice au jeu).

Le principe est assez simple : contrairement aux tower defense traditionnels, où on doit repousser des vagues de créatures, dans CW3, il faut réussir à résister à, puis repousser une substance visqueuse, couvrante, le creeper, qui envahit progressivement la map à partir de spawners qui en génèrent en continu plus ou moins rapidement. Le creeper se comporte comme le ferait un fluide visqueux, en s'écoulant préférentiellement vers les basses altitudes, puis une fois les trous remplis, le nieau de creeper monte, jusqu'à atteindre les altitudes les plus élevées.

Le joueur, de son côté, dispose de trois types de ressources servant à différentes choses (et qui deviendront accessibles au fil de la campagne) :
- L'énergie, ressource de base qui permet de construire des structures, alimenter les armes en munitions, ...
- Le minerai, qui permet de fabriquer de l'anti-creeper, une substance qui se comporte comme du creeper, mais qui le vaporise par simple contact
Ces deux ressources ne circulent qu'à travers des liaisons, que le joueur devra construire en créant un maillage qui sera son réseau de distribution.

- L'aether, qui permet d'acheter des améliorations dans la forge, un bâtiment proposant d'améliorer la production, le stockage des diverses ressources, la vitesse de construction, la cadence de tir et la portée des armes, ...
L(aether ne néssite pas de support pour corculer, et est envoyé directement au Command Center (décrit plus bas).

Contrairement à la majorité des STR, on n'accumule pas de la ressource pour la dépenser, on augmente sa capacité de génération, en unités par seconde. Les ressources ne s'épuisent pas, mais si l'on consomme plus qu'on ne produit, ça ralentit les constructions, ainsi que le ravitaillement des armes. Pas assre d'énergie ? suffit de construire quelques générateurs ... ce qui consomme de l'énergie :). Une mauvaise planification, et on a vite fait de perdre tout ou partie de la map.

Le command center, bâtiment de départ, sert de buffer de petite taille, en recevant les ressources pour les redistribuer en fonction des besoins. Les ressources s'écoulent le long d'un réseau que le joueur devra construire pour être livrées aux structures en construction ou aux armes.

Le creeper détruit toutes les constructions par contact, le but est donc de le repousser en consolidant son réseau de transport d'énergie, et de se frayer un chemin jusqu'au spawner, pour le détruire à l'aide d'une arme spécifique, le Nullifier, qui détruit toute structure ennemie dans un petit rayon.

La campagne, d'une durée raisonnable, propose une histoire intéressante et originale, qui se déroule dans un futur extrèmement éloigné, plusieurs milliards d'années. Personnellement, j'ai beaucoup aimé la campagne. Mais la vraie durée de vie du jeu vient ensuite des maps hors campagne, créées par la communauté

Niveau difficulté, la campagne est raisonnablement difficile (ou facile). Quelques missions demanderont plusieurs tentatives, de même que quelques hauts-faits Steam, mais dans l'ensemble, pas besoin d'être un PGM pour la boucler. Les maps créées par la communauté, par contre, peuvent être très faciles comme très difficiles. A noter que les maps additionnelles peuvent inclure des mécanismes et des structures ennemies absentes de la campagne : un langage de programmation fait maison permet de créer des comportements nouveaux pour les éléments de l'ennemi.

La jouabilité est bonne, les contrôles et l'interface se maîtrisent vite, attention toutefois, certaines missions avec un script particulier nécessitant le contrôle d'un objet devront êtr ejouées avec les flèches plutôt qu'avec ZQSD, les touches pour contrôler l'entité en question étant hard-codées dans la jeu (ou alors je n'ai pas trouvé les options pour les changer).

Côté son, je vais rester unanime avec les autres avis que j'ai vus : très bon, totalement intégré au jeu, exactement la bande son qu'il fallait pour ce jeu.

Voilà, un petit jeu addictif pas loin du sans faute, et pour un tarif contenu, que demande le peuple ?

14530688.review:
I've been a huge Creeper World fan since I played the flash demo of the original release.  It's was the first time I ever paid an indie dev directly for a game.   After losing my serial key, and resorting to pirating, and griefing the dev on his personal forum about how stupid serial keys are, I swore I wouldn't him pay again until I could buy it from a proper distribution service.  Of course I wasn't going to not play CWII, so I pirated just, just like I warned him.  Basically, I've given this dev a lot crap.  At no point, however, have I ever changed my belief that Creeper World is, definitively, the most creative, dynamic, and all around best tower defense game on the market.  

Unlike most wave based tower defense games, the eponymous creeper, somewhat akin to the nothing in Neverending Story, literally represents a tide of battle.  You find yourself struggling to mount a last ditch effort of defense in every map, desparate to get your defenses into place before it washes over you.  As you struggle to build up your (de/off)ense, the waves is getting ever higher, denser, and harder to push back.  Then there's that moment;  your towers start pushing back, you inch them forward and add some more.  The creeper starts to wane.  You close in for the kill.  You have conquered insanity.  It was a close call.

CWII was a unique and addictive game in it's own right, bringing plenty of brilliance to the table, and a completely different experience.  Played from a side view, with a variety of new units and resources, it's very much the Zelda II of the series.  I strongly encourage you to play them both, and I hope he brings them to Steam; I will buy them in an instant.

Creeper World III absolutely lives up to the legacy of brilliance.  Not only does it merge all of the extended unit and resources from the second game into the playstyle of the first,  It refines and expands on the concepts to offer a diversity of experience I simply wasn't prepared for.   I kind of expected more of the same, and what I got instead was my mind blown.

Every map is a righteous experience.  The amount of content is mindblowing.  It's the best tower defense game on the market.    Pay this dev, he deserves it.

14529489.review:
***Written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a unique tower defense game/RTS that is more tower offense than defense, something I haven't seen before. You are a captain of a ship who has just woken up after a very very long time in cryo sleep and in the time you have been gone humanity has vanished as all the civilasations that once were have been wiped out by the creeper, a strange organism which destroys everything it touches. At the time of writing this review I have only put in three hours and have barely scratched the surface but as you can see from other reviewers' play time there is a lot to this game and a lot of replayability.

+Nice pixel graphics
+Simple UI and great controls
+A very interesting story 
+Interesting concept, instead of building towers in the path of an oncoming enemy you create networks of towers and take the fight to the enemy. There are small enemy towers which emitt the creepers which gradually spread across the map, using towers you have to beat back the creepers until your network of towers is close enough to use a special offensive tower which destroys the emitter. The gameplay is quite hard to explain and I probably haven't done it justice so it's best to watch some gameplay videos.
+Your towers can be moved as the creepers are beaten back out of range of your towers
+It's challenging without feeling too difficult or unfair
+The mission menu is an interactive starmap and you get to see your ship travel from one planet or star system to another
+Nice soundtrack
+Can be paused at any point during a mission
+You can create and share your own levels

-Either some people are god-like at this game or the leaderboards have been cheated
-If you make any mistakes with what you build early on in a mission it usually ruins your chances of winning, for example if you don't build enough reactors at the start and you run low on energy later in the game you will most likely be destroyed. It adds another layer of difficulty but it can be pretty annoying

Verdict:
9 

An absolutely brilliant game that is more like an RTS than a TD with an impressively good story, a must buy for fans of either genre.

El K.

14470460.review:
[h1]Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal est un jeu de stratégie très passionant[/h1]

Creeper World est une série de jeu qui a débuté en 2009 avec des jeux en flash (enfin, c’est comme ça que je les ai découvert).

L’histoire est simple, c’est la confrontation entre deux nations belliqueuses, les creepers d’un côté et les humains de l’autre. Chaque nation s’exterminant mutuellement et revenant toujours pour se battre avec l’autre.

Vous jouez un commandant (bien que, vu vos responsabilités, j’aurais tendance à dire que vous êtes plutôt un amiral) et vous devez repousser planète après planète, système solaire après système solaire, les creepers.

Au début, en progressant dans l’histoire, vous allez découvrir petit à petit de nouvelles technologies pour repousser l’adversaire. Mais, rassurez vous, les creepers aussi trouvent de nouvelles armes pour vous attaquer (ou vous contrer).

Le côté positif, c’est que le jeu possède des milliers de cartes, donc des milliers de niveaux, ce sont des heures et des heures de jeu en perspective. Si vous achetez Creeper World 3, vous n’aurez plus besoin d’acheter d’autres jeux pendant des mois et des mois.

Après, on peut se poser la question suivante : quelle est la motivation des creepers ?? Il semble que l’auteur prépare une suite au jeu où il sera possible de jouer le camp des creepers.

14232974.review:
[h1] Woah ! [/h1]

Quelle surprise ! Je connaissais déjà le principe du jeu avant de l'acheter et pourtant il a largement dépassé mes attentes... Pourquoi ? En voici quelques raisons.

[b]Un gameplay sans faute[/b]
Le premier atout de ce titre est bien sûr son style de jeu très particulier. A mi-chemin entre un tower-defense, un puzzle-game et un jeu de stratégie, on doit ici faire face à une menace sans équivalent : le Creeper. Pour ce faire vous devrez construire des canons, boucliers, bombardiers, mortiers, artilleries et autres joyeuseries capables de tenir à distance cette "chose" (disons une sorte de fluide). Mais tous ces systèmes nécessitent d'être alimentés et connectés à votre Command Node, votre QG de départ sur chaque partie. Celui-ci ne pouvant pas assumer seul le débit d'énergie requis pour faire fonctionner votre arsenal, vous devrez construire des générateurs d'énergie. Beaucoup de générateurs d'énergie. 
Car là où le jeu diffère d'un tower défense classique, c'est que vous défendre du Creeper n'est que la première étape : il faut ensuite l'éradiquer, celui-ci ne faisant que se déverser à l'infini sur la carte. Il faut progresser dans un flot continu et mortel de ce truc jusqu'à atteindre la source et la détruire. Et si par malheur vous tombez en pénurie d'énergie... Au mieux vous perdez du terrain et stabilisez la situation en retrait, au pire le Creeper engloutit toute la map et c'est perdu (ça peut allez très vite, croyez moi).
C'est donc un jeu disons "en flux tendu". Si vous avez déjà joué à Supreme Commander, vous ne serez pas dépaysé ici au niveau de la gestion des ressources. Un income par seconde et un petit stock pour amortir les brusques variations, voilà tout ce dont vous avez droit. Et c'est ce qui fait que la tension est constante au cours d'une partie : on observe notre défense, les points où ça fuite, l'énergie utilisée, et quand tout semble à peu près stabilisé on essaye de gagner du terrain. Et on répète le processus petit à petit...
Le gameplay est donc plaisant et maîtrisé qui plus est, avec notamment un système de pause active bienvenue.

[b]Une bande-son parfaite[/b]
Voilà la première surprise que nous offre le titre de Knuckle Cracker : les musiques.
C'est assez simple j'ai rarement vu des OST collant aussi bien à un jeu... Une petite dizaine de piste tout au plus et pourtant on ne s'en lasse pas. Elles participent largement à l'ambiance générale du titre et sont en adéquation avec la trame scénaristique, elle aussi surprenante !

[b]Une histoire captivante ?![/b]
Et oui... Voilà donc la dernière chose que j'attendais de ce jeu : un scénario.
Je veux dire, je l'ai acheté car je connaissais un peu le gameplay via le jeu flash, et je voulais passer à la vitesse supérieure... Mais c'est à peu près tout. Un jeu pareil on ne s'attend pas à grand chose au niveau de la "campagne"... Et pourtant ! Quelle ne fût pas ma stupéfaction [spoiler]la ZerarmY est en marche ![/spoiler] lorsque je me suis retrouvé devant une histoire originale et rafraîchissante, avec des notions que l'on a pas l'habitude de voir. Pour faire rapide et sans spoiler, on parle ici non pas d'une science fiction qui prend place en 2050 ou 2242, mais des milliards d'années plus tard. On ne parle pas de la Terre en particulier, mais de civilisations humaines ayant colonisé des galaxies entières... Les ordres de grandeur sont assez inhabituels et j'ai trouvé ça très appréciable. Car même si la campagne n'a pas une durée de vie très longue, les notions abordées nous permettent de réfléchir sur certaines choses sous un angle différent, et ça fait du bien bordel.


[b]En conclusion, très bonne surprise ![/b] 
Des mécaniques de jeu uniques, une bande-son géniale et un scénario surprenant, que demander de plus ! A mon sens, ce jeu mérite à être plus connu.
Si vous voulez expérimenter le gameplay je vous conseil d'essayer le premier Creeper World, qui est en fait un jeu flash. Disponible gratuitement [url=http://knucklecracker.com/creeperworld/playcwts.php]ici[/url], si vous aimez le principe vous pouvez acheter Creeper World 3 les yeux fermés.

13906300.review:
Creeper World is technically a tower defence game, but unlike any other you've played before.

In a normal tower defence game (and even abnormal awesome ones like [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/MaraKalat/recommended/218410]Defender's Quest[/url]) you'll have enemies coming towards a point or object you're defending and you're tasked with fending them off by placing towers either along a pre-defined path or by creating that path using walls or the towers themselves (this is known as 'mazing').
In Creeper World there is only one enemy, the Creeper. The Creeper is a [b]fluid[/b] of alien origin and malicious intent, it absorbs and destroys anything constructed it touches. This changes the entire dynamic and feel of the game.

The goal (in most levels) is to activate totems that are strewn about the (bird's eye perspective 2D) map without having your base be destroyed by creeper. Creeper flows in continuously from spawn points and you build out a network of structures from your command ship to fend off the creeper (or even destroy its spawn points). The buildings are either combat focused (the traditional tower defence type towers) or utilitarian.
Because the resource system is quite different from a regular tower defence game as well (and is surprisingly similar to Supreme Commander / Total Annihilation instead), you have 'Energy' which is used to build structures, arm your towers and charge up totems. Energy is stored in your command ship and then flows along the nodes formed by the buildings you created, like a spider web that slowly grows outward (and not unlike the creeper that slowly washes over the map).

A simple level progression would be to land your command ship at a strategically good location (high ground, remember that your enemy is basically a liquid so it'll flow into the low spaces first), start building collectors (buildings that gather energy from their direct surroundings) and laser towers to protect the collectors which you slowly move up with the front as the collector field grows in size (all offensive towers can be moved across the map whenever you want).

Of course things get far more complicated later on, with the addition of new towers including mortars, bombers and snipers. New enemies like a creeper-formed network that will always transmit the creeper even if it's uphill, building-disabling enemies living on this network and even aerial creeper that will occasionally spawn from specific enemy buildings and head for your base.

All these things (and a lot more) are slowly introduced over the course of an excellent 30 or so campaign that even has a pretty engaging storyline (the game is set thousands of years after Creeper World 1 and 2, so you don't need to know all that much from them to get the gist of things. Unfortunately they were never released on Steam. For a sample of the gameplay from Creeper World 1 and 2 (and even 3, in case you want to try it out) there are in-browser options available [url=http://www.kongregate.com/games/whiteboardwar]here[/url]).

There is one mission right at the end of one of the two branches of the game's plot that is very different from the others though, and not in a good way. Unlike pretty much the rest of the game it has a time limit, and a harsh one at that. In the rest of the game (especially within the campaign) it's pretty hard to lose as long as you take things slow and don't over-extend yourself. This one mission completely messes that up and asks you to rush in and beat the clock. It's not a bad concept I guess, but terribly executed and I ended up downloading an in-mission savegame in order to bypass it because I just couldn't beat it.

Other than that single (but major) gripe there is nothing but praise for this game. The campaign mode (which will last you a good long while) is only the tip of ice berg, as there are thousands upon thousands of additional levels that you will need a lifetime to complete. These range from fun levels the beta testers came up with, to nasty challenge levels the creator put in, to a whole universe of bonus levels, to procedurally generated levels. There is also an in-game level editor, complete with a way to directly share them with others and play their levels and tools to change anything in the game.

Go give the game's free version a shot, and if the gameplay at all grabs you this is an excellent value purchase. Just remember that there's one super annoying mission in the campaign mode.

13853467.review:
One of the best tower defenses I have ever played. Having played Creeper World and Creeper World 2, this follows the game design of the former. While the graphics may be on a lower end than that of normal games, it provides hours and hours of fantastic gameplay.

For newbies. game elements are introduced to you slowly through the storyline, all the way up to the boss map (hello Thor!). The storyline does build off CW1 and CW2, so you might be a bit lost in understanding any plot and twists. Recommendation to play the first two iterations first - they are both great games.

The game allows you to freely tab out (I'm looking at you Popcap) while remaining in play, and you are able to micromanage and rearrange your defenses when paused - a definite plus. You also get multiple save slots! The speed up buttons are also a wonderful addition - anyone that has played tower defenses will appreciate speed up buttons (1x, 2x, 3x and 4x). 

Plus point is that all your games are cloud saved on Steam - no more having to rebeat the entire storymap and more when you change a new computer or accidentally clear your files! The Alpha and Prospector sector are two such additions which will provide an eternity more of gameplay once you finish storymode. The maps are heavily varied, ranging from small maps to huge maps - all of which will require different strategies. It doesn't feel like you're merely doing the same thing over and over again. And if you ever finish the abovementioned sectors (has anyone?!), there are plenty more user-made levels for you to try out.

An average map generally ranges about 15 - 25 minutes to win. It's a great game to play in between other games for a short break or while waiting for queue times. 

For only SGD15.00, easily worth every single cent. 10/10

13848791.review:
I used to play this ditty on Kongregate! KnuckleCracker still knows how to impress.

You've watched the gameplay, you get the concept - you're fighting a blob; storyline irrelevent. Figure out where to land your HQ and lay out some power infrastructure. Get to the point you can build two power structures at once, build a few sets of two. Construct a laser and mortar, click "stop resupply" and when they're built - figure out which one you need first - click "disarm" and then "resupply" and then do the same for the second weapon. Construct a third weapon, your choice, I prefer mortars over lasers 4/1 so I'd make two mortars.

The trick with mortars and your power supply is, they recharge faster than they fire. So you can pinch off their supply, use it to construct and power other buildings, and stop them - then resupply the mortars more quickly than over-loading your entire power supply would. By playing "half-court" with the power supply, I have been able to greatly improve my speed. Some levels that I've thought were impossible, I've re-visited and been able to beat; some are still impossible.

Some cheats must exist because of high scores. High scores mean nothing though. You play, you win and lose, you have fun, you get frustrated, you leave, you come back and figure out a new layout or move on. It's a good game. I play it often - I mute the music and watch TV on an adjacent screen though. Too much of the music will kill your brain like bathsalts.

13769342.review:
I whole-heartedly recommend this game. Fair warning: you will become addicted to it, and rack up 20 hours playing it in a  single week. I've played it over 10 hours in two *days*.

The trailer, pictures, and even description on CW3's store page fail to do the game justice. It's RTS only in that you can place and move units while the timer is running. It's TD only in that your units only fire while sitting still, and half of your units can't move once placed. Allow me to paint you a different picture of this game. The creeper is like water that bubbles up from the ground, and you can't touch the water...because you're a cat with a lot of really cool turrets. Each of your turrets does something different. Half of your turrets aren't offensive devices; they're used to set up the infrastructure of your base, collecting resources, etc. Your energy recharges continuously, but your base can output more energy than it collects, and will eventually reach equillibrium with your input. When you start to net energy income, do you build more energy collectors, or new weapons? Eventually, you can terraform the map at large energy output, but you don't need the terraformers on constantly. Want a turret at a different location to combat the creeper? Your offensive turrets can fly. to new locations, but if your infrastructure hasn't caught up to the front, their ammo stores will drain rapidly.

Each map is essentially a series of multi-step problems that can be solved in a variety of ways, especially as you unlock more turrets. Early in the game, it's pretty obvious what tactics the map maker had in mind, promarily because you haven't yet uinlocked all of the turrets. But not even half-way through the initial campaign, you come to understand the myriad paths you can take to solve each particular step of a problem. Terraforming is a big part of this: because you can literally change the shape of the map, setting up infrastructure one way opens up different solutions down the road.

The two extremes of the spectrum of CW3 players are probably Speed Runners <----> Slow and Steady. I'm the latter right now, which is one of the reasons missions take me so long: I spend more than half the run-time with the timer paused. But you've got to be careful while paused: queue up too many turrets, and your production rapidly outpaces your income, slowing your entire system. The game doesn't punish you for being either kind of player--on most levels, your resources don't dwindle over time, so you could play a single map for hours in a trenchy-style of building one row of turrets just in front of your previous row. The game *does* punish you for not paying attention--being fast is definitely doable if your minimalistic solution has all of the right components. 

CW3 is a phenomenal example of the adage: gamers prefer good mechanics to good graphics. But don't let the 2D simplistic art scheme fool you. Not only are the mechanics solid, the performance stellar, but the interface is also straight-forward, and the controls seem pretty intuitive. Left-click to select, right-click-hold to move around the map. Zoom in/out with mouse wheel. Escape to un-select or exit out of a selection. The visuals and animations tell you what you need to know, and if something isn't working like you expected, it's pretty easy to figure out why.

I wouldn't say it's a difficult game in the initial campaign, but it *is* intense regardless of your strategy. There appear to be scads of maps that the community has created that will test your skills, as will the Challenge section by the developers, *and* the custom-level editor is built right into the frakking game.

Geez...I haven't even gotten to the Titans yet....  :}

13753380.review:
This is a gem of a strategy game. It's a RTS Tower defense-esque game, this might not sound like a good idea, but it works beautifully. There are two main mechanics that I will address:

1. The Creeper. This is your enemy, it's a liquid entity that creeps forward from spawners, slowly covering more and more of the stage. You need to build towers to fight it back, and in turn advance farther along the stage yourself. Creeper would be very difficult to deal with if it didn't obey the laws of physics. Basically, in order for creeper to overflow onto a higher level of terrain, it has to have nowhere else to go on its current level. This leads to some fairly interesting placements, like a very powerful spawner at the bottom of a deep crater. There are plenty of other enemies too, runners and digitalis namely. Runners just run along digitalis and need to be destroyed with sniper towers, they can't directly destroy your towers, but can stun them long enough for creeper to overflow onto them. Digitalis is a kind of grid-like enemy that conducts creeper and prevents towers from being built, trust me, it's more difficult than it sounds.

2. The Network. This game has parallels to a tower defense game, but calling it one doesn't do it justice. The biggest conventional differences being: Towers are networked, they have to be connected to your base to function; Towers can be moved freely, even off the network, albeit with limited ammo; towers use energy, constantly.

The biggest difference as I stated is the network. You have to build collectors and relays between towers to provide pathways for the "packets" of which there are three types, ammo, construction, and totem. This means you can't just build towers in the most strategic spots right away, you have to build out to them, often fighting tooth and nail to get to them. Additionally, these packets cost energy, which is distributed evenly between the active types of packets, energy is obtained through collectors, which collect energy across an area, and reactors. Collectors gain no benefit from overlapping area and should be spread out, they are also one of the main staples in your network of towers. If you get too ambitious with your expansion, you'll enter energy starvation, where packets are produced less efficiently and you run the risk of your blasters running out of ammo and the line being pushed back.

Between the campaign mode and the hundreds of other levels in the game + fan made ones, you could get hundreds of hours out of this game (I didn't because I just played creeper world 1 and 2 before it and was done after the campaign). Having played all three games, this is the best. 

Even at full price, I think you'll get your money's worth, this is a difficult game, you will need to think strategically and act quickly. It's a refreshing change of pace from most RTS and tower defense games in my opinion.

13750912.review: Although it may look simple – the mechanics and controls certainly are – Creeper World 3 proves to be surprisingly challenging. 13728482.review:
Playing TD's as a youngun, who recently discovered the wonders of the internet, were absolutely incredible times. But I always got a bit tired of the repetative movement of putting down another tower, upgrading them blah blah blah.... and then just leaving the game to run it's course, throwing wave after wave of enemies until your computer began to stutter and lag behind as it was somehow managing to cope with an incredible array of pixals being thrown into your eyeballs. I am mainly talking about the infamous Bloons TD, which will always remain my favourite TD, although there are others. However, this game is a little different in that respect. 

I like to think of it as a combination of a TD and RTS, in the sense that The Creeper, some blue liquid thing, is not stuck on rails and just has to get from A to B as it floats down a path ignoring all defences on its journey, it is instead open to go where it pleases, only limited by the geography of the landscape. The RTS element in the game is the fact that you build up cannons to protect your 'base' and resource collectors. They take time to build and must be placed strategically in order to maximise the efficiency of your defence and keep The Creeper at bay. After that, you must push forward and move your defences forward even more. But they can get delinked from getting resources, so extenders are put in place. On large maps, it can be very rewarding seeing a huge web of links and seeing your packages of Anti-Creeper and firepower flowing down these pathways. 

In later missions, more enemies arise and give even more things to think about when planning out defences, but don't worry. A reasonably nice variety in defence types can help with that. But you'll have to play it in order to find out what.

13537445.review:
Surprisingly good game series and it's growing in quality, complexity, polish and number of titles. It's actually real time strategy rather than tower defense -- much more dynamic and fun.

The creeper is the enemy; there are structures on the map which will produce waves of creeper, which are hazardous to your units. Some structures will launch creeper artillery into the middle of your infrastructure. You use weapons to defend yourself and push the creeper back. Towards that end, you must acquire and manage your resources. Your objective is to destroy enemy offensive structures and the score is determined by how fast you can do it.

The high variety of maps presents a unique challenge every time. You can play it safe and ensure victory at lower scores, but the real challenge comes when you strain yourself and your units to win as fast as possible.

13487619.review:
This game is listed as Tower Defense game, but its less about defense and more about pushing a wave back to its source.

Essentially your enemy isn't a monster, a beast, a beam of light... its water (this game calls it creep) and in order to stop creep from extending you have to push it back and turn off the faucet. Your enemy has no path, it goes from high to low, and can be channeled like a river or as even as a ocean.

Is it the best defense game you've never heard of... ITS NOT A DEFENSE GAME ITS AN ASSAULT GAME. Your not fighting to stay alive... your fighting to stop the expansion of your opponent any means necesary.

Story is ok... its deep and enriching but if you want to ignore it you probably will.
Gameplay is complicated, yet simple... just watch out for Farbor, if your a slow player you will not finish farbor
Music is repetitive and generic... its like 4 tracks on autoplay. The sounds are meh
Replayability? Do you like to play for time, play lots of maps, creator is very deep...

I've always had a thing for RTS and Tower Defense games, and so when I first found Creeper World on Kongregate, I was overjoyed. There were many different versions available freely there. Recently, I decided to purchase the third installment to see how it was.

There is much to love about this game. The game follows more or less the same rules throughout, but the final two story missions are definite game changers. I've seen many complain about losing on the second to last mission due to time constraints - I myself lost the first time around, but with a little advice I figured out how to beat it. The consistency of the gameplay can make things a little drab if you play too much, but if you enjoy one level, you're likely to enjoy a whole lot more - and there are a whole lot more. There's an practically endless array of levels once you beat most of the story. You can binge play or play a game every once in a while - either way, it will take you a long time to run out of official maps, and you'll never run out of custom ones. The game isn't all too challenging if you remember to pause frequently and keep tabs on the Creeper and your resources, but there are more difficult levels available if that's what you're looking for. The graphics are solid - nothing incredible, but well-done nonetheless.

A seemingly simple, easy to pick up RTS with mechanics that afford incredible depth. Reminiscent of Total Annihilation (intentionally so, given the inclusion of the signature bertha cannon) and the under appreciated gem perimeter.

Each level in the campaign introduces a new unit or a new mechanic or just has some kind of unique property to make it interesting which is really the key to any decent RTS campaign. After you 'finish' the main story there is a bounty of user designed maps, wacky beta tester maps and 2 'sectors' of conventional maps with a specific goal in mind, not to mention the ability to design your own maps. Not only is the replay potential limitless it's also really good content in its own right, some of the use made maps are really fun and if you beat it in the fastest time you get to 'claim' it as your own.

If you're into oldschool RTS like red alert 2, starcraft or the aforementioned TA this the ultimate indie game, you wont get a better experience for your money.  I honestly can't believe this was developped by one guy given the amount of content squeezed in and the elegance of the design.
