12284366.review:
While my playclock there is probably half again what I have actually played, I have played a lot of this game. I have a few top 10 high scores (look for Seika), I've completed the story, and whole heck of a lot of missions in Tormented Space area (hard mode), so I have quite a bit of familiarity with the game.

Pros:
-A unique take on strategy that generally emphasizes resource and space management more than managing unit tactics, and the enemy is a rather literal tide rather than a more discreet set of units
-Huge array of playable content, with a wide variety of maps.
-Once you clear the main campaign, there are three main modes of pre-constructed maps. Prospector Zone has literally hundreds if not thousands of hours of content, Tormented Space exists for a good challenge, and Alpha Sector has some interesting and often difficult custom maps.

Cons:
-There is little to no AI to speak of. Certain types of enemies are capable of either roaming around randomly, and another will target random sections of your grid, but otherwise, the enemy will follow a strict pattern every map. Except for speed running, there is little point to replaying a map.
-Music will get repetitive.There is a mute button for a reason.
-Once you clear the main campaign, there are three modes. Prospector Zone is where much of the game's content lies, but the (generally) lower difficulty and lack of custom scripting means that most of these maps will get boring and repetitive. Tormented Space is not always the best tested: Some maps will feel almost as easy as the tutorial, while others are quite literally impossible without cheating (there is a thread on the Knuckle Cracker Forum dedicated to which maps are super difficult, which are insanely difficult [often requiring odd tricks in order to even stand a chance], which are possibly impossible, and which are undeniably impossible). If I have any complaint about Alpha Sector, it is that many of these maps were designed by some of the best players to be at their level, so it can be hard to make progress through those missions.

The game can feel repetitive, particularly playing too much in too short a time, but the game has kept me hooked. I would recommend playing this game to anyone who enjoys puzzles and strategy, or who likes playing unique games.

Creeper World 3 is a delight to play, the various modes and tools make for a great rounded experience.

Campaign: The story of the game is discovered piece by piece, each level add little things as you are introduced to new towers, brings variety with occasionally slightly different objectives and few levels feel like you have played this before. Even the wider galaxy maps vary enough to warrant a look through. Each level has it's own leader board, and while most levels are hard to lose, you can be overrun and set back (mostly costing you time) if you don't pay attention to the whole level.

Editor: The Editor provided allows for easy placement and adjustment of basic objects. but there is a deeper level if you look into the forums, you'll find out quickly that you can run custom scripts and make your own objects (or just fiddle with what others have made if you lack the programming knowledge)

I never played the first two Creeper World games. I didn’t even know Creeper World was a thing, it flew so far below my radar. The third came highly recommended to me by someone and it was on sale, so I figured why not. Trying new things is part of the fun of gaming. Thankfully, you don’t need to have played either of the previous games to enjoy Creeper World 3, as it has a mostly self-contained plot.

There’s no getting around it: the game looks ugly. The graphics are utterly functional, and that’s it. But this ugly duckling has a supernova of elegant swans that explode from its superdense core the moment you start playing. Arc Eternal follows a well-written science-fiction plot as you fight an enigmatic foe known only as “Creeper”.You can place turrets, mortar launchers, build bombers, cannons, and terraform the terrain to redirect the Creeper’s endless flow, provided you have the resource generating capacity to sustain it all. By the end of a mission, the sheer scope of your network of energy-producing Collectors can be impressive.

The campaign is lengthily with many unique map elements. There’s a huge amount of side-missions and bonus content if you’re up for it, and the Dial-a-Map Device can generate infinite random missions.  Creeper World 3 is impressive where it truly counts.

Réadaptation d'un jeu flash bien connu, le nombre de méchaniques différentes qui ont été ajoutées par rapport à ce qu'était ce jeu à ses tout débuts sur l'internet est impressionant. Le principe reste identique, du creeper envahit des maps (avec une gestion de la profondeur du terrain) et il faut contenir sa progression puis attaquer pour se faire un chemin jusqu'à la source d'émission pour la détruire. Cette mécanique ce qui malgré le level design ingénieux fait que les parties se ressemblent énormément (passé les premiers niveaux dans lesquels on découvre les nouvelles technologies les unes après les autres). 
Le jeu propose une grosse quantité de cartes, que ce soit à travers la campagne solo ou les campagnes bonus, qui occuperont les fans pendant bien longtemps, et la possibilité d'utiliser des cartes faites par d'autres joueurs permettra encore d'allonger la durée de vie à volonté. Hélas, malgré toute la bonne volonté mise en avant et les ajouts de gameplay, le jeu reste très répétitif et on identifie rapidement des techniques qui permettent d'avancer et qui reposent souvent sur les mêmes combos. 
Une valeur sure pour les fans du jeu original, pour les autres, préférez tester la version d'origine ( http://knucklecracker.com/creeperworld/playcwts.php ), si le gameplay vous rebute ce jeu ne vous conviendra pas.

Pros:
A unique blend of RTS and Tower Defense is an innovative twist on a tired genre.  Seriously.  I'm utterly shocked nobody else has stolen this and applied their own game to it yet.
Maps vary wildly in difficulty, taxing your ability no matter how experienced you are at the game.

Cons:
*If you have a technical issue, the developer's response will be "It works for everyone else, it must be a problem on your end.  Good luck fixing it.*  If you buy this game, try it immediately to make sure everything's kosher, so you can return it if it something doesn't pan out.
Story is short and painfully one-dimensional.
Balancing issues abound.  Since the enemy never gets any stronger, and you never stop getting stronger, surviving the first few minutes is tantamount to winning the map; Clearing emitters is a formality.
Some maps are 100% objectively impossible to beat.
Certain achievements aren't so much "achievements" as "medals for playing a really really long time."

--
That said, the game is worth playing for no other reason than to experience the unique gameplay.

11852010.review:
This is not a traditional tower defense game.  You don't build mazes.  You don't upgrade towers.  There are no units to attack.  Yet, it contains a lot of the same mechanics as TD games:  you build towers which attack for you;  you decide whether to spend or invest resources; you strategically place towers at the right places and times.  Thus, I don't feel uncomfortable categorizing this in the Tower Defense genre.

The game goes like this:  you expand your base to earn resources.  The larger the surface-area of your base, the more resources-per-second you earn.  Meanwhile, the "enemy" is simply a geyser of fluid [i](called "creeper")[/i] which spreads out in all directions.  If the fluid touches a tower, that tower dies.  You use your towers to push back the fluid, so you can get close enough to destroy the geyser(s).

On paper, it sounds stupid.  But then again, I would have said the same thing about TD games at first, and now they are my favorite genre.

In reality, this is a [i]fantastic[/i] game.  The game constantly introduces new gameplay-elements throughout the campaign, keeping it fresh and unrepetitive.  The levels are never too easy, but also never too hard [i](the main campaign, at least)[/i].  And after beating the campaign, the game opens up hundreds of levels created by the developer, his friends, beta testers, etc. giving this game immense replayability.

I've played [i]a lot[/i] of TD games, and this is one of my top 3 TD games of all time [i](just behind [url=http://www.pathery.com]Pathery[/url] and [url=http://www.teamliquid.net/forum/sc2-maps/420656-ums-entropy-td]Entropy TD[/url])[/i].  If you enjoy TD games, I personally guarantee you will enjoy this game. 10/10

This is a great take on tower defense, with an emphasis on budgetary consumption and harvesting of resources and an enemy threat that is not unlike trying to hold back a flood.  Each level tends to be a puzzle, and the harder boards are those having the fewest number of valid solutions.  Very easy to just pick up and play, and I'm still coming back to beat levels long after finishing the main game.

You deploy your repositionable towers as you see fit, but must keep them connected to your network.  Units cut off from your network wither and die quickly.  Once you stabilize your economy (assuming you can), you transition from defense to offense to win the map.  Get good enough on the regular levels, well, by gosh, they have hard ones and then super hard ones to break your will.  

They also rank your performance against others on the web, so you can see how bad you suck.  All in all, this a great strategy game.

11690389.review: Auf Creeper World 3 - Arc Eternal bin ich zufällig über die Kategorie "Neuerscheinungen" bei Steam gestoßen. Es handelt sich dabei um einen erfrischenden Strategietitel, der vieles anders als die Konkurrenz macht. Eine gallertartige Masse namens "Creeper" überschwemmt nach und nach jeden bewohnten Planeten des Universums und löscht auf diese Weise alles Leben aus. Jeglicher Versuch, diesen Vormarsch aufzuhalten, ist bisher fehlgeschlagen. Wir springen ein paar Milliarden Jahre in die Zukunft, wo wir wiedererwachen, uns an den alten Auftrag erinnern und feststellen müssen, was passiert ist. Über eine lockere, teilweise etwas dünne Handlung treibt einen die Geschichte von Planet zu Planet, wo wir mit immer neuen Herausforderungen kämpfen müssen, den "Creeper" zu verdrängen und benötigte Gegenstände zu sichern. Der Spielablauf bleibt variantenreich und man hat immer das Gefühl, viele Lösungsstrategien zu haben. Wer sich von der einfachen Grafik nicht abhalten lässt, findet bei Creeper World 3 einen interessanten, innovativen Strategietitel, der einen mindestens 25 Stunden lang beschäftigt. Nach den Storymissionen gibt es noch hunderte weitere ins Spiel integrierte Welten zu entdecken. Wem das noch nicht genug ist, der findet auch noch einen angeschlossenen Workshop, über den man gratis Userkarten herunterladen, spielen, diskutieren und bewerten kann. 11685922.review:
A good game, but with issues in its "packaging".

I knew the series from the previous Flash chapters. The developer did a good job adding enough elements to this episode to keep the gameplay interesting throughout the campaign.
It's an interesting strategy game, where you know how the enemy will behave from the start (since it follows fluid physics) and yet every map requires you to think about how to approach it with the land provided and the techs unlocked. The gameplay is solid, it is decently challenging for a first walkthrough (yet nothing a player with any experience in the genre will not be able to tackle) and offers a chance for speedrunning/score attack replays of existing maps. Apart from the campaign (which took me somewhere between 8 and 10 hours at a leisurly pace), the game has a couple extra modes with different objectives, for even more longevity.

The problems I have with the game are mostly outside of the gameplay itself. The game asks for a relatively high price tag for a series evolved from a Flash game, but does it add enough to make it reasonable? In my eyes, it doesn't.
The storyline is ridiculous, it pretty much revolves for the entire campaign around the idea of "I lost my memory, what's all of this?". You could skip every dialogue in the game and not miss anything relevant. The only campaign progression is the gradual introduction of more buildings and techs.
Which leads to the second point: after you unlock everything and you figure out which approach works best for you, most of the extra modes are more of the same. Which is good if you want to play more on different maps, but it lacks the tailored scenarios of the campaign. Still, it's good to come back from time to time for a map or two and have a large selection of unexplored locations.
The graphics haven't improved in a relevant way compared to the Flash chapters. The soundtrack is very limited and you will get bored of the few track really fast.

All things considered it's still a game I'd pick up, but at a sensible discount, since it's reasonably fun to play for a while but lacks the added value to justify the price point.

11491135.review:
Creeper World 3 is one of those funny little games that don't quite fit any established genre. 

It's broadly speaking an RTS, but it doesn't really play like any other RTS on the market. It also has some tower defense elements to it, but again, it's quite different from any "true" tower defense game.

Like a TD, it's a game about fighting a relentless enemy that keeps coming at you along predictable paths.

Like a regular RTS, you build structures to harvest resources, and your towers can move around (this is [i]very[/i] important on many levels) once they're built.

Your enemy is a liquid with no ability to react to your activities. It simply spreads from emitters and flows downhill, forming pools that eventually overflow and flood the map. There's no enemy AI worth mentioning. And it's still surprisingly challenging, because there's a [i]lot[/i] of the stuff, and your resources can be quite limited. You'll have to make careful decisions about where to build something and [i]when[/i] because running out of power at the wrong time can cause your entire line of defense to collapse in a real hurry.

It's a very simple concept, with only a few types of unit, a very straightforward upgrade system and extremely barebones presentation...and it adds up to a highly addictive game with surprising depth once you get into the tougher maps.

All in all, I can definitely recommend this.

11402744.review:
Creeper World combines strategy, resource management, and meditation.

Ok, technically you can just crank up the speed to remove some of the meditative aspects, but usually on those levels I'm too busy micromanaging my energy flow moment by moment to do that.

If you've played the other Creeper World titles you'll already be familiar with the franchise approach - the enemy is simply evil water, and you're equipped with a variety of anti-water weaponry that costs energy to use, while you seek to reach and destroy the faucets that spawn your dire nemesis.

With a reasonable single player campaign and a huge quantity of additional levels, there's plenty to keep you busy.  Level quality can vary a great deal, with some really clever ones, and some that are truly just boring, with little to warn you which will be which. 

Even so, if you enjoy this sort of challenge, you'll find you have a lot of quiet moments of personal accomplishment where you puzzle out some elaborate resource management or timing issue.  The game has a lot of depth, and even once you've polished off the campaign, there is loads more playtime to be had.

Overall, good stuff.  If you enjoy strategic puzzles and resource management then this is an easy buy.

11047421.review:
Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a under-the-radar tower-defense game that is both fun and challenging. It's basic yet complex appearance may overwhelm those new to the genre, but Knuckle Cracker did a good job on slowly pacing the user into the concepts around Creeper World 3. 

The graphics of Creeper World 3 aren't anything extraordinary but they are pretty solid. The terrain is in a variety of colors and the illusion of layers is clearly there. The various tools and weapons stand out from the terrain and are simple to realize through the variation in shape and color. While everything looks basic throughout the game, the graphics are crisp and clear - and that's good enough for a tower defense game. 

The core gameplay of Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is one that is new to me. While I have played other games in the same sort of genre, Creeper World 3 is unique in the sense that it's attempting to fuse both Tower Defense and Strategy-Simulation. While the majority of tower defense's have you place your weapons on a certain path as enemies start to come at you on a predictable path - Creeper World 3 is adds a refreshing twist. Your enemy is the creeper. The creeper spreads outward in all directions, covering the terrain and destroying everything in it's path. It is your job to use the weapons at your disposal to take out the source of the creeper - being the emmiters. While it may not sound that hard, which it really isn't at first; the difficulty begins to ramp up. It will be very challenging for newcomers - including me at times, but I never really felt that the game was cheating. I also realized what mistakes I made if I were to fail. Throughout the game, you will play a variety of maps with the inclusion of the story. The story arc is the weakest point about this game, it's very forgettable and did nothing to increase the immersion or gameplay. It's a good effort nonetheless. The mouse controls are also great - with the ability to pause the game, plan you moves and move your units around where you please. Overall, the core mechanics of Creeper World 3 is great and will be something for all games in the similar genre to beat. 

The audio is good for a game like this. In all honestly, what can you expect. The music is fine with the occasion of it being repetitive. I found myself turning off the music at various times. The sound effects are pretty simple. Nothing special here.

Creeper World 3's greatest strength is it's value. Like Skyrim, Portal 2 and Torchlight 2 before them, the sheer amount of user content is mind-blowing. At a cheap price of $15, it's pretty hard to not pick this one up if you are a fan of the genre. There are an abundance of maps, both pre-made and user-made all varying in difficulty. It's also good to note that some maps have been known as unbeatable. A random map generator is also here as well as an in-game editor to create your own maps for others to try. Creeper World 3 also has over 130 achievements for those who are into them. 

In conclusion, Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal was one of the more surprising buys for me. I didn't think I would enjoy the game this much. It is something I will continue to play for years to come. 

GRAPHICS: 8.0/10
GAMEPLAY: 9.5/10
STORY: 5.0/10
AUDIO: 7.0/10
CONTROLS: 9.0/10
VALUE: 10/10

OVERALL: 8.1/10

+Refereshing take on genre
+Challenging yet Fun
+Solid Controls
+Addictive
+Great Variety in Maps and Units
+Overwhelming amount of content 
+130+ Achievements
+Inexpensive

+/- Some Unbeatable Maps

-Weak Story
-Repetitive Music
-Can sometimes be a grind

SUMMARY: 
A unique and interesting RTS/tower defense sci-figame. You use nodes to create webs which energy then passes through to power your weapons/defenses and beat back the ever-encroaching purple creeper "mist". Its addictive and you will have the temptation to go "one more level" everyime you think you're going to quit. The graphics and sound are adequate, but not great, But who plays these games for the graphics? If you are an RTS/TD fan, this game is defintely one to pick up even at full price. It's tiny bit pricy at full price for those who arent die-hard fans of RTS/TD games, but if you see it on sale, get it!

MAIN:
This game is fascinating. Its a really unique RTS/tower defense, the style of which vaguely reminds me of the Zerg in the original Starcraft. But there are no barracks for units, no movable parts. No vespene gas.

You have awoken in space after a 5-billion(!?) year stasis sleep, to find that the Creeper has again rampaged around destroying humanity's galactic empire. Of course, you must stop them. Its kind of difficult to explain how this game works without seeing it, but I'll do my best:

The Creepers have emitters which slowly start filling the map with purple stuff. If this purple stuff touches one of your buildings it is destroyed. You need to destroy all the emitters to progress. Sometimes there are other objectives as well.

So you build a command center far away from the emitters. Then you start building nodes and weapons such as cannons. Each node creates lines to the nodes next to it, and power flows through these lines from the command center to your weapons/cannons as well as newly placed buildings to construct them. Cannons cant link to each other, but only to nodes and relay nodes. So you want to build as many nodes to create a web, then a front line of weapons to hold off the onslaught, slowly building more relay nodes and weapons as you manage to beat back the "purple mist".

 The nodes also generate energy, which you need to power your cannons and build things quickly. Build too fast, and your energy goes out of balance, weakening the ammo resupply to your cannons and allowing the evil purple stuff to overrun them.

There are also specialty nodes, such as relays which speed up energy transmission to new nodes and weapons, reactors, which provide lots of energy, special weapons, and many others I havent seen yet.

Theres a lot of strategy, figuring out the best place to put your nodes to create fast transmission of power as well as beat back the purple mist, but not overbuilding so you end up overrun. 

Missions are timed, although as of yet I havent seen any where you "must beat the mission in (x) amount of time", but I wouldnt be surprised if they were out there (I hate those types of missions...I'm naturally a careful player who tries to do/see everything in any game I play. I HATE being rushed.). The fun of being timed is a global leaderboard where you can see rankings of how fast people have beat the missions.

The graphics are nothing to write home about, just little representations of the terrain, units, your node web, claimed territories, ect. But who cares? The strategy is what matters here, and I'll take gameplay over graphics any day of the year.

Sound is the same as graphics. Its ok, but nothing spectacular. Lots of pew pew and booms.

Overall, this is a unique and interesting game. There appear to be many many levels to play as well as a storyline. Its really fun, and if you see it on sale is a must buy for any RTS/tower defense fan.

10870947.review:
見事なまでの時間ドレインゲー。気づいたら10時間近く経過、これはヤバイ。

■ゲームの概要■
Creeperと呼ばれる敵を駆逐していく面クリア型RTS・TD（タワーディフェンス）ゲーム。
ガントレットやInfested planetをTDにした感じ、というとかなり近い気がする。


■特徴■
敵であるCreeperは、なんだか液体に近い挙動。MAP上の発生源から、放射状に広がっていく。
ただ広がるだけでなく、高いところから低いところへ優先的に流れていく。

自分の兵器は意外と種類自体は少ない。砲台は3-4種類位しかないし、
補助タワーも同じくらいのバリエーション。
航空兵器も今のとこ3種類、うちひとつは飛び地への輸送機なので攻撃機能はない。
そのほか非攻撃タワーが8種類（リソースの回収など）。
こちらの兵器の最大の特徴は、HQ（本陣）にリソースタワーを介して接続しておかないと、
建設自体ができないし、仮に建設が出来ても、攻撃用の物資が必要なのでやはり接続が必須。


■なんかアリの巣の近くに昆虫を落っことした時みたいな夢中度■
正直言ってそこまで革新的なゲームでもないような気がするし、
見栄えは正直そうでもない、音楽や効果音は結構爽快感や没入感があっていいが・・。

が、なぜか面白い。次のステージ、次、次と先に進みたくて仕方が無い。
MAPひとつひとつがよく考えられていて、パズル的な楽しさがあるからだろうか。
難易度曲線や、ステージデザインが絶妙だからか。
なんだかんだ考えていたが、どうも見てるのが楽しいと言うことに気づいた。

上述したように、各種タワーを建てたり利用したりするにはリソースを
輸送する必要があるが、それが全て可視化されている。
なんだかよく分からん丸っこい建築物資や、恐らく弾薬かなんかだろう、
赤い球状の何かがタワーとタワーの間をギュンギュン飛び交っているのだ。

なんだかコレを見ていると、まるで人の体内を見てるような、なんともいえない楽しさがある。
（トレイラーにあるので check it!）
ジワジワと広がってくる粘っこい液体のようなCreeperと、ミニミニしい砲台たちが
ちょこまかギュンギュン飛び交う物資で戦う・・・。
そんなものを眺めていると夜になっているのだ。不思議。


■総評■
よっぽどストラテジーゲームが嫌いな人で無い限りは損しない。
特にちょこちょこちっちゃいのが動き回ってるのが好きな人は、マストバイ。
自分で言うのもなんだが本当に
・なんかアリの巣の近くに昆虫を落っことした時みたいな
感覚を味わえる。
ちなみに坑道を探検したり、クラフトしたり、家建てたりはできません。
それはただの病気です。

10856085.review:
What a great game! I've put quite a few hours into it. For those of you put off by the fairly simplistic graphics, don't be! It's the [b]gameplay[/b] which is the real selling point of this game.

For those of you on the fence, imagine attempting to fight a tidal wave. With guns. And mortars. And another tidal wave of your own. And sometimes really big guns. The Creeper is a living liquid that makes Tiberium look like a small chemical spill. It's coming for you from all sides and directions. It cares not for the small base you've built, only for consuming everything.

So dig in. In some levels you'll have to do this quite literally, as terraforming is a tool at your disposal. In some levels you'll be hanging on by a thread, almost consumed the second your power goes down to build that reactor you need to expand. In other levels, you will actively hate the liquid that is all set to consume everything you've worked so hard to create.

But you will love every second of this game.

A really unique concept which will keep you entertained for hours on end. Gets a 9.5/10 from me!


One more thing! As mentioned to me in the comments, there is a demo version of the game on Kongregate. Check it out if you're still undecided!

There are also free demo versions of the game you can find on steam or the internet, so try those out before you buy.

10828358.review:
Damals, als ich bei einem Internetportal für Flashgames den ersten Teil dieses Meisterwerks spielen konnte, hätte ich nicht erwartet welchen Lauf die Geschichte nehmen würde. Heute steht er da, der dritte Teil eines Spiels, was für mich die Perfektion in Tower-Defense darstellt. Warum? 
Fangen wir von vorn an. Die blauen Creeper breiten sich aus, sie sind dein Feind. Dies passiert schichtenartig, d. h. die blaue Masse breitet sich von einem bestimmten Punkt immer weiter aus und zwar auf verschieden hohen Ebenen. Die vorgegebene Landschaft bestimmt mit ihren Gegebenheiten wann die Creeper bestimmte Orte erreichen. Deine Aufgabe ist es, mit Anti-Creeper, Türmen, Bombern und Kanonen dagegen zu halten. Das ganze basiert auf einem Energiesystem welches du dir erst aufbauen musst, es gibt viele Gebäude die für deine Infratruktur zuständig sind und ebenso viele Waffen stehen dir zur Verfügung. Das ganze macht erst richtig Spaß sobald der Schwierigkeitsgrad etwas angestiegen ist. Keine Mission spielt sich gleich, du musst bei jeder Situation neu entscheiden und strategisch vorgehen, sonst ist das Spiel schnell vorbei.
Der Clou: Die meisten Waffen sind beweglich, dadurch ist das Schlachtfeld sehr dynamisch. Später erhält man ein Gebäude das Upgrades freischaltet, z. B. lassen sich Feuerrate und Reichweite der Waffen erhöhen oder der Energiespeicher ausbauen. 

Ich bin aktuell bei Level 20 von 50, obendrein bietet das Spiel Online-Support und Spieler können ihre eigenen Level erstellen und hochladen. Die Grafik ist stimmig und Effekte werden stilvoll in Szene gesetzt. Der Soundtrack verdient hier eine besondere Erwähnung, dieser ist zwar nicht dynamisch an das Geschehen angepasst, aber durchaus atmosphärisch und verleiht einem das Gefühl man würde für eine große Sache kämpfen.

Missionen dauern teilweise bis zu 45 Minuten und erfordern viel Geschick, mal eben schnell in 10 Minuten eine Mission zu spielen ist nicht so einfach.

Ich kann jedem, der etwas für Tower-Defense Games sowie Strategie übrig hat, nur empfehlen mal einen Blick auf Creeper World III zu werfen.

10821813.review:
I picked this game up one afternoon during the summer sale and started playing.

When I stopped, it was shortly before sunrise.

So it's rather successful by that measure. It's quite satisfying to take back ground from the creeper, and when one word is safe, jump right into the next. One more level. I don't think I've played the other Creeper World games, but it feels like after years of making them they've got a pretty good handle on what makes a Creeper World game work in that regard.

I've just finished the main [u]Arc Eternal[/u] campaign, after 27 hours. (I play defensively and pause a lot. Your mileage may vary.) The campaign is pretty good at making each level just a little different, providing some new element of challenge and giving you a new ability to use. Some levels are more different than others.

The game's weakest moments, I think, are the maps that become simply an ocean of creeper. Any distinctive features of the terrain are all but lost under the sea, as you slowly entrench and advance. Maybe more aggressive tactics could prevent ending up in that situation, but since I wasn't actually [i]losing[/i] those battles, I didn't give up and try different techniques. Then came along a different map that makes things interesting again.

This isn't the sort of game you play for the story. Yet there is a story, told in bits of dialog at the beginning and ending of levels, which shows some significant thought has gone into the lore of the Creeper. I might have appreciated it more if I was familiar with the other games, but it provides some interesting atmosphere.

I can't comment on the other content outside the main campaign, but there seems to be a lot of it, with a strong focus on giving the community powerful tools to make more.

I played this on Linux (Ubuntu 14.04). Everything ran great there; the only hitch I found is that after switching out of the window with Alt-Tab, I had to hit Alt again after returning to the game to get the keyboard input recognized correctly.

To sum up: Surely not everyone likes this style of game. But if you're interested in this sort of thing (which you likely are, if you're looking into the reviews), I recommend it without reservation. It's an excellent implementation of the idea.

And also very good if you want to forget to eat or sleep.

10754484.review:
ストーリー曰く
主人公は５０億年の眠りから目覚めたが、自分の他に人類は見当たらず、宇宙の片隅で事務的なAIと二人きり
自身の過去と人類の痕跡を求めて訪れる惑星で人類を消失へと追いやった謎の敵Creeperと相対する事になる。

やたらとスケールのでかい話しに若干置いていかれそうになるが、ストーリーを理解しなくてもゲームは充分に楽しめるので英語が苦手な人でも楽しめると思います。
ただストーリーマップ序盤はチュートリアルもかねているので、マップ開始時に会話の中にギミックの説明もまぎれていたりするので流し見程度には補足しておくといいかもしれません。
本当に重要なものはゲーム開始時にテキストで説明されるので大丈夫だと思いますが。

一見タワーディフェンスのようなゲームに見えるが、どちらかといえばお互いの領土を押し合いする陣取りゲームのような内容で、
タワーディフェンスは限られたリソースでいかに効率良く自軍をアップグレードしてどう敵を捌いていくかが面白さの主軸になっているが、
このゲームのリソースはほぼ無尽蔵、序盤のリソースの増やし方に制限はあるものの時間をかければひたすらにリソースを補充し
「戦いは数だよ、兄貴」と言わんばかりに膨大な量の補給ラインとタレットで敵を押しつぶすのが主なゲームの流れだ。

敵のCreeperはコアとなる部分から水をこぼした様に広がっていき自分のテリトリーを拡大していくのだが、高低差の概念があり水のような性質のCreeperは高い場所にすぐには上がってこれない、
他にも砲台のようなものを使用してきたり、Creeperの進行が早くなるガーゼ状の地形やこちらの設備をスタンさせてくるお邪魔虫など様々なギミックが用意されているようだ。
そういった要素を踏まえつつ、スタート時点でマップを把握しどこに防衛ラインを引くか見極めまずはCreeperの侵攻を食い止めながら、補給ライン構築やリソース確保などのインフラ設備に勤めよう。
このまずは防衛、そして攻勢にという流れが実によく出来ていてチマチマと陣地を拡大していくのに夢中になってしまう。

筆者は現在１０時間ほどプレイしているがストーリーマップの1/3も終わってないように思える、
タレットなども全てアンロックは出来ていない、
正直これは自分がクリアの目処がついても延々と自陣の拡大にはまったりしていたせいだと思われるが、
それでも尚かなりの量のマップが残されているのは確かなようだ、なんせストーリーマップクリア後には新たにチャレンジングな３つのマップセットがアンロックされる上にユーザーメイドのマップも既に膨大な量が上がっている、
はっきり言って全てを遊び尽くすのは無理なんじゃないかというボリュームである。

オプションなども設定出来る項目は多くUI周りも不備はない、ちなみにCreeperはデフォルトで水のようにブルーカラーに設定されているがこれも自由にカラーを選ぶ事が出来る。

ユニークなゲーム戦略、圧巻のボリューム、どちらもプレイヤーを充分に満足させる内容となっているが
個人的にはCreeper World 3最大の魅力は別にある。

なんというか、美しいのだこのゲームは
幾何学的に広がる補給ネットワークを血流のごとく流れる物資
アメーバのように広がるCreeperの侵略を休む事なく迎撃し続ける砲台と戦闘機
コア破壊時の高鳴るチャージ音にはカタルシスさえおぼえる
その全てが生態系のような循環を感じさせ、マップクリア時には一つの世界を創造したような気分にさせてくれる。

いささか大げさな言い様だが、こういった感覚は開発者も理解しているようで、マップクリア後もそのままゲームを続けて自分の構築した世界を堪能できるようになっている。
けして美麗なグラフィックでもないため見た目で敬遠してしまう人もいるかもしれないが、是非一度は触ってほしい作品である。

10381079.review:
J'avais déjà apprécié il y a quelques années les versions flash de l'opus 1 et de "Creeper World: Evermore". J'avais ensuite zappé le numéro 2. Pour ce troisième Creeper World, j'ai retrouvé tout ce que j'avais aimé auparavant malgré les nombreux ajouts. C'est un RTS de science-fiction où vous devez combattre du creeper, un sorte d'entité fluide qui ne cesse de se propager et qui détruit tout à son contact.

Le jeu propose une campagne (environ 30 heures pour en venir à bout), un éditeur, des cartes d'autres joueurs, une section "Tormented Space" avec des maps très difficiles à impossibles, des mondes générés aléatoirement et j'en passe. Il manque juste les parties multi-joueurs, mais comme je préfère jouer en solo, ce n'est pas vraiment un problème à mes yeux.

Les graphismes peuvent sembler assez basiques, mais, dès la première partie, cette simplicité permet de rapidement repérer chaque unité ou type de bâtiment. Une fois concentré sur la stratégie, j'en oublie complètement ces représentations élémentaires. Le seul petit problème est de distinguer les zones envahies pas le creeper, celles où se trouve l'anti-creeper (généré par certaines de nos armes) et les zones d'influence des collecteurs de ressources. Il est possible de changer les couleurs du creeper et de l'anti-creeper, mais je ne suis pas réellement arrivé à trouver une bonne combinaison de teintes.

La prise en main est aisée. Personnellement, je n'utilise que la souris et deux touches du clavier. La touche "Espace" pour désélectionner une unité et "P" pour mettre le jeu en pause. La fonction pause est essentielle car l'on peut donner des ordres précis comme la construction de bâtiments ou le déplacement d'unités. Sans cette possibilité, il serait très difficile (surtout sur les larges cartes) de jouer au vu de toute la micro-gestion indispensable au bon déroulement d'une partie.

Le jeu est en anglais uniquement, mais les textes sont peu nombreux et courts. Parfois lors de la campagne, il est préférable de comprendre comment fonctionne la carte proposée grâce aux dialogues qui peuvent apporter des indices précieux.

J'ai beau chercher, il m'est impossible de trouver de gros défaut à ce jeu passionnant et plaisant. Je le recommande chaudement à tous.

Ma note : 9/10.

10348272.review:
Despite the title, this game has nothing to do with Minecraft! This is the first game I've bought in a long time at full price,  and it's worth every penny.

Creeper World 3 is a pausable RTS-type game with aspects of tower defense at its core, combined with a physics/fluid dynamics twist. The game is very well done, challenging and packed with a number of game modes, along with a powerful integrated editor. It's not ridiculously complicated with dozens of units or a mad clickfest where you need millisecond reaction times to survive -- those games are not really my style, but Creeper World 3 is very satisfying. It can get hectic, but there's always time to pause and breathe.

Terrain (including terraforming), energy networks and advancing your weaponry all play huge roles, and you will definitely be pondering strategies on every map. This is not a puzzler, there's not a single "right way" to win each map; given enough time, often times even poor strategies can grind out wins. That translates to a lot of flexibility and support for different playstyles and setups.

As the title suggests, this is the third entry in the series, so there's a level of polish and streamlining over the previous titles. There are a huge number of community-created maps, variable-driven procedurally generated maps, and advanced scripting options available in the editor to create a large variety of scenarios beyond just basic maps. You could basically play this game for the rest of your life and always see new content. Steam cloud, achievements and online leaderboards round it all out.

Try the free demo at the developer's site to see if it hooks you like it did me: http://knucklecracker.com/common/demo.php

10302123.review:
I've played Creeper World since I first saw the flash version of it online, and have been hooked to it ever since. I saw this on Steam and I instantly knew I had to buy it. Plays just like the first Creeper World, on an overhead view of the map. If you've played Creeper World 2: Academy online, you'll have some of, if not all of what you need to know about the characters in this game. The story is pretty entertaining, I found myself wanting to play more every time I finished a mission. 

If you're one of those people that couldn't care less about the story of a game, and only care about the gameplay itself, it's got more that what you could ever possibly want. The amount of levels in this game are enough to last you for a loooong time. Each level is different, each one is difficult, and each one forces you to think about how you'll need to start. Sometimes you'll be cornered, sometimes surrounded, and sometimes you won't even have a lot of time to prepare. You would start off in an area with a high wall that has holes in it, and the creeper is advancing from all around you, you can only seal off a few of the holes. In some levels you won't have much time before you're overwhelmed, and in some you might need to use different strategies. This game will have surprises in store for you if you're new to it's universe and gameplay.

As for the levels, I have yet to put even a small dent into the other sectors, as they contain probably hundreds of more challenging, and maybe even impossible levels. Even with the story missions, as I progressed through them I found myself taking almost an hour to beat them. This will be a time consumer. And on top of the other sectors, there is also the DMD, which is basically loaded with user created maps. So if you somehow manage to top every single level with the game, there's plenty more where that came from.

If you've played Creeper World before, you will definitely love this game. It's all of the original gameplay loaded with levels, some new tools, a map creator, and, in my opinion, a story that will leave you wanting to continue and find out what happens next.

10163253.review:
So, first things first, this game is not the best written and graphically designed, and that probably turns some people off. I am very pleased that I fall outside of that group because it is a terrific game. The basic mechanics are all easy to understand, shooting the creeper makes it decrease in level, creeper moves like a fluid (though I've heard it's simulated more like heat. But for all gameplay purposes you can think of it like a viscous fuid) to fill in gaps, you need to send out packets made from energy to supply turrets, construction and other things. 
Then as these gameplay elements start to overlap the interactions between them get more complex. I won't go into too much detail but there is a special type of terrain that promotes the creeper to flow along it. This may completely throw what you were doing previously because suddenly you have to be cautious with the fact that it is much harder to clear the creeper.
The main draw of the game to me was the resource management system though, which forces you to manage between the space needed to get energy, how much you can afford to defend with that energy, and how you can expand from there. It is very easy to find you've just spent half an hour gradually shifting around units to allow you to push forwards, but all of that time feels engaging.

Overall it's a very engaging game and at £12 it's decently priced for the amount of gameplay contained within.

10049808.review:
Creeper World. (This is a review for the trilogy which you can get through links on the developers website for about $25 and includes a Steam key for the third game, which is the only game currently on Steam)

The Creeper World trilogy are RTS games, with a twist. The enemy is not (most of the time,) a specific unit, but instead a wave of blue goo that must be held/pushed back in order to achieve your goals. There are enemy units later on in the second and third games, but every level will be about beating the goo to some extent. 

The feel of the game is somewhat similar to a tower defense game at times, but not so constrained. Most of your 'units' are emplacements/turrets, albeit ones that can usually be moved when you need them somewhere else. 

The complexity of the game increases throughout the series, (so I would recommend starting weith the first game and playing through the trilogy,) but never felt stale even in the first game. The second game changed the style of the game somewhat, and whilst interesting and fun, it wasnt as engaging as the first game, and fortunately the third game returns to the style of the first. Dont get me wrong though, all three games are good. 

There is a story, but its a minimal affair, a paragraph or two at the start of each mission, sufficient to add a bit of colour, but ultimately nothing to get excited about. 

There are also downloadable demos for each game available on the developers website if you want to have a go and see for yourself. http://knucklecracker.com/ including a web based version of the first game.

So, any drawbacks? The graphics are simplistic but functional, the same is probably true of the sound effects/music. but I tend to turn it off and listen to a cd anyway. The interface is a bit basic, could do with a bit of love and a bit more control, ie text sizes etc, but other than that, its an RTS and its a good one, with map editors, a lot of missions built in and literally thousands of player generated maps too. 

As such, it is absolutely recommended.

9914153.review:
(Originally posted April 3 2014)

I just finished the main campaign of Creeper World 3 today, a unique tower defense/RTS game that uses a thermodynamic simulation to control the "Creeper", a fluid–like substance that must be combatted to conquer the game's levels. A return to the top–down perspective of the original Creeper World, this game also incorporated many elements of the previous sequel, Creeper World 2 (which had a different perspective and significantly different mechanics).

While I enjoyed this game very much, my biggest complaint is that the performance suffers when you have too many units built, which hampers my preferred turtle/juggernaut strategy. On some of the large maps, even playing at 4x speed the gameplay would slow to an interminable pace. Aside from that reservation, I'd certainly recommend this game, particularly to RTS and tower defense enthusiasts. The story is bat–shit crazy, but who plays this kind of game for the story?

There's a link to my review in the Steam description above, but I figured I'd post some content here as well.

"When it comes down to it, “Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal” keeps the addictive quality of the original alive and then some.  The extra content is just icing on the cake and almost assures return visits. In terms of whether or not it is suitable for kids, I’d have to go on record and simply say, “yes”.  There is no blood/gore and as an added bonus, it promotes critical thinking in that you’re forced to tackle maps in a systematic way.  Coming at the creeper from one side may not work, for example, but establishing a foothold elsewhere might be what you need to advance.  In a sense, this game is not only a real-time strategy/tower defense hybrid, but it’s also part-puzzle and will certainly make you think.  This combination is great for kids and adults alike, in my opinion.  All in all, “Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal” is a brilliant addition to an already fantastic series.  While this game is without a doubt a keeper, there’s a free demo on the official website (link below) should you wish to try before you buy."

9825221.review:
It's World of Goo vs. The Blob! 

The Creeper is a simple, slow moving liquid and you have a literal army of sophisticated gadgets to fight it. However, you need to gather resources, build defenses, and figure out how to actually fight back while The Creeper ever slowly creeps closer and closer. At least, that's how things start out. Soon, you begin to find out why multiple human space empires could have fallen to this deceptively simple-looking enemy...

Each level provides a different challenge, and after you play a few levels it becomes obvious why this game has three installments already. It doesn't look like much, but then, neither does The Creeper. The game itself, like The Creeper, is deceptively easy to underestimate, but if you like strategy games, building games, or puzzle games, you should give this a try. There's nothing quite like it.

9793130.review:
A few months back, I bought this game after seeing it featured on a Let's Play channel that I follow. I loved it. Now it's featured on Steam, and that was worth me buying the game again.. :V

Essentially, Creeper World 3 is a simple, yet very addicting RTS game. Your task: to liberate planets from the Creeper, which is a living liquid substance that had flooded and destroyed civilizations for millions of years. The story mode campaign is pretty much an extended tutorial that teaches you about all of the gear and units that you will acquire along the way. Once you have gotten so far into the story mode, you can unlock access to other Zones, which is where the game truly opens up.

These Zones have tons of star systems, each with their own collection of planets. Basically, you are free to explore hundreds (if not thousands) of levels of Creeper-fighting goodness. There is also a Map Editor mode in which you can create your own maps to upload to the community. You can also download maps that others have created, and rate them. If all of that [i]still[/i] isn't enough, there is a "Dial Map" service, which is a seed-based random map generator. So many potential battlefields..

So, yeah. Great game. Keep on fightin' that flood!

Excellent.

The inclusion of a full suit of level-design and modding tools ensures that there's a massive amount of gameplay here, even if you don't try to get a high score on the "core" levels, which is difficult indeed.

TL;DR: The ultimate king Canute simulator.

9738062.review:
What a game.

I wasn't familiar with the previous titles in the series, but this is absolutely great.
Admittedly the game isn't really pretty and might put some people off, but gameplay-wise this is a gem.

I mean... how many games do you know where the main mechanics are attrition, network building and logistics?

At the start of the game I completely disregarded the story, but I quickly found myself wanting to know more... and the story is actually well-written and interesting! Which, I have to say, was a surprise (the game would have been as good without any story whatsoever).

Also, the pacing is great... every level holds a new mechanic, a new unit or a new obstacle to overcome.

The content is also monstrously gigantic, with custom maps, challenges, etc.

Now, not everything is perfect... the instructions on how to play are way too vague and the lack of tooltips coupled with odd terminology makes it a bit hard to get into. The UI is functional but could have been better.
Also, people who might panic when there's too much much stuff going on might not like it...

Despite all of this, it's still a fantastic experience and real surprise... especially considering that nowadays games tend to fail to hold my interest for more than a couple of hours.

I'll be keeping an eye on knucklecracker's future endeavours.

Além de ser extremamente desafiador, Creeper World 3 é um Tower Defense totalmente diferente do que eu já havia jogado. Isso porque o inimigo é um líquido, cujo nome é o que se dá ao jogo, que destrói tudo que passa pela frente, sendo assim, você deve planejar sua estratégia para evitar que ele destrua completamente a sua base.

9716148.review:
Creeper World 3 is a game that will catch you off guard. Unless you played the flash versions- then It's just more of the same, in an extremely good way. Beyond Creeper World's flash-era graphics, midi-era music, and long dialogues of exposition that seem to go on for ages, is a complex fun game that is more than your average tower defense.

I feel like it would almost be putting Creeper World to shame by simply just calling it a tower defense. It's more like it's own unique style of RTS, pitting you against the mysterious force simply called "The Creeper" (aka water) that is constantly spreading at an alarming rate. Your goal varies from mission to mission, either a simple one such as "Get from point A to point B, destroying everything in your way" to "activate these 6 thingies, go over here and kill this, and then do a loop formation with your towers and then go...." etc etc. The game varies it's missions very well, making every planet seem like a distinct new world with it's own gimmick rather than just something thrown in a level generator. The towers are extremely situational, and I actually like this more- there's no "Jack of all trades" tower, forcing you to vary your strategy depending on what is happening in front of you.

This all sounds very complex, and possibly at the later levels it is. But as of writing, I have not completed the first sector as I am taking my time enjoying each level, and it is quite managable. I have not tried the extra features that seem very interesting such as DMD, Colonial Space, and Tormented Space, simply because I do not want to spoil the towers for myself- but these seem all like extremely cool features to add replayability to the already large campaign. DMD Allows you to name a randomly generated map after beating it, allowing other players to play and rate the map and name for themselves. Colonial Space is a sector of space only containing user generated maps, and Tormented Space is full of hard bonus missions.

Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a beautiful game so far. It's mediocre graphics might not seem like it's worth 15 dollars at first glance, but this is much, much bigger than one might expect. If you like the base game, there is infinite replayability here with much more towers and many more planets to explore.

9711530.review:
Unique and addicting, this tower defense game ranks up there with the very best in its genre.  Instead of fighting off enemies one at a time while they march on a base, this game has players holding back seas of purple slime.  Depth, density, and volume are all significant factors when planning your strategy against the slime emanating from various points on each map.  Where players are usually expected to only defend their base in traditional tower defense games, Creeper World has the added final, and extremely satisfying, goal of pushing through the slime and destroying the source. 

If that was all there was to this game it could still easily be considered great; its community support through the map editor and its features however, makes it fantastic.  Players can create generated maps according to specified criteria, design maps from scratch themselves, and then upload all of these in-game to be played by the community.  It's one of the most simple and easy to use map editors I've used - I just jumped right in and never even looked at the tutorial.

If you like tower defense games, this is one you want for your collection.  And if you don't like tower defense games and you're still reading this review it's probably because your noticing how uniquely awesome this game is and you haven't even played it yet.

9701499.review:
A satisfying game, where the enemy is totally predictable (it is literally as dumb as thick goo), yet no less challenging for that. 

The eponymous "Creeper" is a thick sludge that spews out of emitters in the game world, and you must force it back. The creeper isn't smart, it doesn't think, and it doesn't even have anything in the way of AI. What it has instead, is a pleasingly viscous fluid simulation. It flows downhill, it pools in low areas, and it can't cross high terrain without building up behind it and overflowing it like a dam. This is the key to the game. Work out where the creeper will flow, and divert or destroy it to survive and achieve your objectives.

The game is one of thoughtful management. Rarely is there urgency, except during scripted missions, or if you seriously mess up and end up watching a purple tidal wave swamp your low-lying energy collectors. That's okay! The challenge is one of incremental advancement and the satisfying conquest of areas that were drowned under a layer of creeper 8 stacks high. 

I'm a little concerned with balance issues (there is one early-acquired unit which seems overpowered, especially in groups) but I'm content to tend my garden of creeper without abusing it, which is an unusual state of affairs.

Every win feels satisfying as the AI can't cheat and the levels are well designed.

Very addictive and a bargain at full price. Similar to the first Creeper World but better in every way.

9691745.review:
[h1]At the Time of Writing[/h1]
[b]Game:[/b] Creeper World III
[b]Price:[/b] $16.99*
[b]Genre:[/b] Tower Defence/Strategy
[b]Time Played:[/b] 2 hours
[b]Personal Enjoyment Rating:[/b] ☺☺☺☺☺ (out of 5)

[b]Links I Found Helpful**[/b]
Game maker (Knuckle Cracker) website has demo downloads. [url=http://knucklecracker.com/common/demo.php]http://knucklecracker.com/common/demo.php[/url]

A Youtube review by [b]quill18[/b][url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SlJ5FmjL_7g]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SlJ5FmjL_7g [/url]

[h1]General[/h1]
At the time of the writing of this review, I've currently played a mere two hours of this game. I am hooked. Although the videos of the game make it look complicated and mask its true nature, I can assure the reader that it feels like a proper tower defence game. I am a big fan of the StarCraft "turret defence" games of old, and I'm particularly enamoured with TD games which allow you to maze. This game may not involve mazing, but you can freely place buildings and "towers" anywhere you deem fit. Do not feel dismayed by the lack of monsters and lack of paths. The "creeper" (which is the enemy) is a creative way of presenting said enemy. It is much too easy to think of it as StarCraft zerg creep to be honest, and needless to say it is not nice stuff. I feel that this game has been lovingly crafted, and I'm looking forward to the replayability that other reviewers have mentioned.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Your objective is to defeat the creeper on each world. You do this by building up an energy grid and using that energy to build and maintain various weapons (akin to the traditional TD tower). These weapons can move to a new location as you push the creeper further back, and they can be upgraded at the forge.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
You use the keyboard and the mouse. All of the buildings, and many actions are linked to hotkeys, and those hotkeys can be rebound. Unfortunately the build menu does not tell you the hotkey when you hover, so you must go into the key bindings menu to discover what the hotkeys are in the first place. However, once you've learned them they are easy to get along with.

[h1]Storyline[/h1]
There is a plot in the Arc Eternal galaxy. It is fairly basic, and mostly explains the existence of the creeper. I didn't know what precisely was going to happen, but I certainly had a general idea of what direction the plot was going in. But this isn't the sort of game you play for the plot after all.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
The music is fun, it's energetic. However it is very repetitive. If I play this in the evening, I go to bed with the music stuck in my head.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics are pleasant and functional. Things seem a tad fuzzy if you zoom in really close, but I personally like to have an overall view of the map and so I don't zoom in close. Otherwise, despite all the layers upon layers of creeper, the game runs quite well for me and is not laggy.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]+ [/b]non-traditional tower defence
[b]+ [/b]free placement and movement of "towers"
[b]+ [/b]can rebind hotkeys
[b]+ [/b]default hotkeys make sense once learned
[b]+ [/b]make your own maps and play others' maps (great replayability)
[b]+ [/b]wide range of difficulty level (depending on map)
[b]+ [/b]first levels of campaign form a tutorial on how to play
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]- [/b]music is repetitive
[b]- [/b]hotkeys are not immediately obvious

[h1]Help Me Help You[/h1]
[b]If you did not find this review helpful,[/b] I would really appreciate your constructive criticism - tell me why it wasn’t helpful for you. It’s my hope to make the reviews that I do take the time to write up, as helpful as they possibly can be.

[b]Footnotes[/b]
* Any prices that I mention are in CDN because that is what I see. The primary price I list at the top is the price that I bought the game at.
**I will not be keeping an eye on whether the links are up to date, so if they are broken I apologise. Remember that these are external websites and I'm just trying to be helpful - I'm not responsible for the content on the other end.

Yes.  Yes, yes, yes.  I bought this game because its cross-genre TD/RTS looked nice, and because of the overwhelming horde of good reviews.  I'm happy to add my own to the mix.  There's not a lot I can say that the video doesn't cover, except that it controls real well and the challenge is an appropriate level.  Currently my favorite single player game in my library.  I'm about fifteen hours in, and there's at least another ten left for me.  Apparently it's kind of like Populous, with hordes of randomly generated worlds to play on.  Looking forwards to it.

This game reminds me somewhat of Immortal Defense.  While the gameplay is entirely different (it bends "Tower Defense" in the opposite direction), if you're the kind of person who gave that a try, you should probably try this as well and vice versa.

There's one keyboard-throwingly hard mission late in the story, but it doesn't end as soon as you might think.  Trying to keep this spoiler free, but I did almost unjustly ragequit, so don't give in.

It's like a Tower Defense game and a real-time strategy had a baby.

Do you like the combat puzzle of TGDs? Do you appreciate the magnificent sprawl of your towers? Does the average TGD leave you feeling like all you do is sit back and wait for the enemies to make their move? Then have I got a game for you!

Creeper World 3 is the TGD that forces you to be aggressive. This game changes the Tower Defense rules so much that it is debatable if the term "Tower Defense" should even apply.

This is definitely one of the most addictive games I've played in a while. I highly recommend it.

On the downside, the graphics are rather poor (but about as good as can be for the simple top-down view). The music is good, though a little too upbeat, and the songs are short, making them repetitive.

If you're still not quite sure what to expect, give the demo a try.

I'm enjoying this game, but I really don't like being forced to go through the campaign (which has levels that can become quite tedious).  There's no access to some advertised features until the campaign is finished.

Okay - if the campaign is good, let it stand on its own two feet.  Don't use it as a "job" the player has to work through in order to get to the features that looked interesting.

WHAT THE GAME HAS TO OFFER:

This is a subtle balancing act between building up energy and mining operations at the right pace versus building up weaponry.  What I like about this game is the subtlety.  You might be tempted to build a lot of things only to run out of energy and then nothing gets done.

There are also interesting fluid dynamics to work with/against.

9682214.review:
Creeper World 3 is a fun and innovative take on the strategy/tower defense genre. Your main enemy is an ancient, liquid based entity that spreads throughout the universe, destroying all in its path. In order to kill the Creeper, you must build an energy network, build turrets to push it back, then destroy its source. 

There are a wide variety of tools at your disposal, various types of turrets, shields, terraforming devices, attack craft, and even the ability to manufacture your own creeper, to name a few. This creates considerable depth, by giving you the choice how to tackle the various missions.

On the subject of missions, there are a lot of them. In addition to a main campaign (which does a good job of introducing players to the nuances of the game and the many units), there are several other sectors, numerous community made maps, and a dial a map function which allows for map generation. In short, there's a lot of hours fun to be had. 

In addition to great gamplay, the visuals are nice, and there's some really great music to play along to. I've encountered no bugs in my time playing. This is a game I would unconditionally recommend to strategy & tower defense fans. Even if strategy isn't normally your thing, CW3 is quite different from the usual fare, and you may well find something here to your liking. Well worth checking out!

9672358.review:
The Creeperworld series is by far one of my favourite time wasters. Like others that I have read, I played the first 2, including the extra missions, all on Kongregate and eagerly awaited this third installment. I'm so glad to see it here on steam as the Dev can finally make a decent buck from his amazing efforts!

What makes Creeperworld games so unique amongst other tower defence games is the energy currency system. Unlike other games that require you to save your resources, research, etc etc until you can build what you want, you have the ability to build straight away and as many of each structure as you like. The danger lies that the energy required to build, is the same energy required to fire weapons. So if you exhaust too much energy into building, you will surely die! This is balanced by the fact that the more "collectors" you spread across the map, the more energy you have, so there is always an incentive to keep building! 

Although not as graphically amazing as some TD such as Kingdom rush, Giants and Dwarves, etc or even the older Dune 3D, Starcraft, etc, etc it makes up for it in fantastic TD gameplay. The second installment of the series seemed to push for better graphics, though this actually seemed to tear away slightly from the charm of Creeperworld and I am personally glad to see an this version return a bit truer to its roots... With one great advantage... NULLIFIERS!! You can explode those nasty emitters. Something that you dreamed heavily about in the first game. 

There are a bunch of new features in this third game all which so far (I know it's still early for me) are very welcome imrovements. One of the best improvements has to be the TERP that literraly allows you to redraw the level!! No space for that turret... No problem, I'll just terraform some extra land in there :) It's a low price for a game that will guarantee you hours and hours of addicting gaming.

Slamming down a review like Pogs right now.. And I've only (shamefully) played less than 3 hours, BUT I'M QUALIFIED. This game is great :P I wanted my review to be my original thought about the game from looking at the screenshots, which was:

"What are tho.. Ah, so.. The lines mo.. uh.. Wait, then those bubb, er.. And they.. ? What is tha.." :P

In short, this game is about the primal fear of water ruining your cool stuff. Imagine your kitchen. Its awesome. Except now you've decided to catalog your prize comic book collection, THE WHOLE THING. Its going to take a while. The table is
 piled so full that you've had to start making piles on the floor here and there. Suddenly, your child drops a full glass jug of apparently antique milk and it shatters!! *suspenseful music* Now, the antique milk hasn't splashed on your comic 
books.. YET!

But its spreading!! And, lucky you, besides collecting comic books you also design small functional mortars and cannons that fire small liquid-absorbing sponges, all supplied by intricate wiring relays that transport power from a central battery. For the sake of cohesion we'll say you developed the sponge cannons because of your mortifing phobia of dish cloths, also, so you can't just mop the liquid up.. *cough* If you're quick enough, you can set up an intricate web of relays linked to your tiny armada of sponge-launching war-machines aaaall along the kitchen floor in a milk-encircling radius and potentially combat the comic-ruining liquid menace before your precious copy of Jurrasic Park #1 is ruined.

That's what the game is about. Yep.

In all seriousness I think its pushing it to call this game a tower defense game.. I tend to reserve that title for games with MUCH less features and elements involved than this, particularly concerning tightly placed pathways. As stated elsewhere, if you have any doubts about purchasing, the first two games are on Kongregate free to play, and there is also a demo of this game on the devs website. But you don't need a demo. Did you need a demo when you decided air was good to breathe? Did you!? ;)

Also I wanted to mention that til this game showed up on Steam I had no idea it existed, so there is that :> I'm fresh as a daisy to this and can already smell the deep possibilities here and have barely touched the main campaign just yet, but I still hope the dev isn't fully done adding to the main game, especially since its life on Steam has just begun.. Now if I can just muster a little focus and make time for myself to play..

This is a surprisingly compelling little game.

The gist is that you are fighting back against goo of the sort you'd expect to find in a dystopian science fiction novel. To do so, you maintain an array of collectors interconnected by an energy grid that conveys construction and ammunition resources throughout its network. You plunk down turrets, which can later be moved, that feed off the grid. The goo itself has a few tricks that complicate matters, but I'll leave that to you to discover.

What sounds simple ends up making for a fairly compelling asynchronous RTS. Wrapped in an intriguing story, and garnished with pleasing graphics, it ends up being a fun ride.

9659767.review:
I've been a fan of the series since the original.

In a nutshell the game is hard to put in a nutshell. It's vaguely reminicesent of tower defense titles, but with an absolutely monstrous, game-defining twist. The enemy is not units, but rather Creeper-goop that covers the map and damages or destroys your structures on contact. The game is to fight back, and then destroy the goop spigots-"emitters"- or complete other objectives. The structures and enemies are all very simple and direct in their purpose and utility. The game itself however is extremely various in difficulty based on the map itself-size, features, and the strength of the emitters. There are additional enemies in addition to the emitters but they are not in all maps.  The challenge of the game is all about defending yourself while you build your energy resources up before you push to destroy the emitters. Later, you can redo the maps to attempt to do so faster. 

The game has a great custom map communtiy and a custom map generator after you finish the decently long and challenging campaign. Replayability is top notch.

I've gotten more fun and more hours out of this than a shameful number of AAA titles. All things considered, absolutely amazing for an indie. 

I've had no issues with bugs, and the developer has been pretty good with support for those that do find them.

The only downside is there is no direct multiplayer of any sort. However, it really doesn't detract from all that you're already getting in this well-fleshed out title. 

Newbie Tips:
-There is no such thing as too much energy 
-Stick to high ground when you can
-Don't land near emitters
-Don't build too many structures at once
-Don't botch your startup
-If you don't push, you can't win

Full disclaimer: I am a huge fan of the first 2 creeper worlds, the following review maybe … ok it is totally biased.  (Also,  Big thank you to the one of the sweetest guys in the world for buying this for me before I could buy it for myself!)

@ 9 hours in--

I flat out knew I was going to love the third installment of the creeper world saga; but I was unexpectedly blown away.  I was pulled right back into the story and found myself once again needlessly spending 30 + minutes covering planets in collectors and eliminating all traces of  creeper before clamming my wins just because I could. Quickly new mechanics were introduced and my strategies needed to be adjusted, keeping the game play from being stale for returning players.  The game includes a awesome tutorial for new comers … but I would start at the beginning of the story and pick up the 3 pack (for just a few bucks more) at the developers site: http://knucklecracker.com/

The game is a must buy for lovers of strategy and tower defense games.

I'm not a big RTS player, but I found myself playing this for hours, upon hours - straight. This game doesn't look like much, but it delivers an interesting twist with the gameplay that I haven't found in many RTS games. EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE, you have been warned!

I'd say it plays like a slower style RTS like Supreme Commander, mixed with tower defence. However, there is a strong online competetive speed running intention behind this game. Best of both worlds kind of thing I guess. You can make and share your own maps. Play and complete on other people maps. I love how little download wait time there is between trying new maps. Literally, a few seconds.

The down sides, I'm not a huge fan of the artwork. I find it corny and unpleasnt looking. Nonetheless, it works somehow in this setting. There is also a lack of diversity, variation, and depth, with the units and enemies. Each unit has it's strict purpose like in a tower defence game. The outcome can become rather predictable and static. But don't let that stop you from trying this game! It's really fun.

9647438.review:
(日本語レビューは下のほう)

This Strategy game is about fighting liquid-like enemies called Creeper, which aren't explosive but dangerous enough to damage/destroy your buildings on touch.

Game is relatively simple : Build a network of Collectors for more energy. Have some turrets to keep Creepers at bay. Advance to their Emitter and destroy it with Nullifier(its range is short and takes time to activate, be sure to deal with creepers first).
It contains more than thousands of official levels, short maps are finishable within 3 minutes or so, and some epic maps would take 2 or more hours. 
There's even a leaderboard competes for "time taken to beat the level", and some people seem to be really good at finding clever tactics or optimize their moves.

The game has a built-in map editor and script editor, which allows you to make interesting maps once you know how. I'm hoping to see good levels to play.

12/10, One of the best RTS I played in all the time. I played all the 3 series of Creeper World, and love it best.

--------------------------------
液体状の敵「クリーパー」と戦うRTS。緑色の爆発する皆のアイドルではない。

ゲームプレイは比較的シンプル。「コレクター」を建ててエネルギー供給とネットワークを作り上げ、各種砲台でクリーパーと戦う。どんどん前線を押し進めてクリーパーの発生源である「エミッター」を破壊する(ただし破壊できる「ヌリファイアー」は建設に時間がかかる上に脆いので、発動までちゃんと守ること)。
マップは公式で用意されたものだけでも数千以上あり、３分程度で終わる小型マップから数時間かけて攻略する難易度や規模のマップまでバラエティは豊富。
クリア時間を競うリーダーボードもあり、上位のスコアの異常な速さは戦略の自由さと効率化の重要性を語っている(チートの線も否めないレベルってのもあるが)。

あとマップ/スクリプトエディタも同梱で、作られたマップを公開、他者のマップをプレイして評価できる機能もある。これからのコミュニティの動きに期待できる。

個人的点数は12/10。「最高のRTS」と聞かれたら挙げられそうなレベル。３作ともプレイ済みだが、３を一番薦めたい。

9502257.review:
I hate this game. You should never get it. Seriously. Once you have this, it will be a time sink forever. You can never finsh this game. It's a deceptive little game - you may think - "oh, there are only 23 missions in the Story  then I'm done."  But it's not so easy. Along your way you will unlock untold millions of additional maps. Then you can't stop playing them.

I have been playing Creeper world since 2009 and I can't stop. I need to join the Creeper World Anonymous club and confess "Hi, my name is Karsten and I can't stop killing Creeper."

You can play in the Tormented Zone if you are a masochist and like inflicting pain on yourself. Some worlds in there are [url=http://knucklecracker.com/forums/index.php?topic=14333.0]documented unwinnable[/url] - but that won't stop you from trying - it didn't stop me.

Occasionally venture into Prospector zone and pick up a few Artifacts of Odin - the mightiest weapons mankind did not invent. 

Try out the Alpha sector. Made by those early beta testers. Made to be difficult. Make sure you try Virgil's Brainic map. Just to see how weird you can get.

Like Shooters? Try out the Credits mission.  Hey, my name is in there somewhere - so are all the other beta testers. :)

If that's not enough, go dial up your own maps in the DMD (Dial Map Device), Here you can make a world with the click of a few buttons. Add ingredients to suit you and cook up a hard challenge or a speed run - win it, name it and share it with all us us addicts. Oh wait, I'm trying to stop playing. Don't share it.

Finally, if you are creative, inventive and perhaps you like to add custom units and styles, make your own map in the Projects Editor and share it in Colonial Space. Here there are no rules. Maps are all over the place, fun, hard, tricky, unusual, huge slog-fests, or tiny puzzles. As large as 256x256 or as small as 20x20.  Don't say I didn't warn you. This is where "map rage" goes to live after you discover it at Farbor (the timed mission in the Story arc).

I would tell you more, but it's time for my fix and Im heading out to the DMD to get a quick fix.

Oh yes, "Hi, my name is Karsten and I am killing Creeper."

I've been a huge fan and supporter of this series ever since I've found Creeper World 1 on Kongregate. The game is worth every cent and if you're a fan of non-hardcore strategy games (or a time attack player) who likes territorial expansion and variety then this is a game for you! If you're a story kind of person then I recommend starting from the first title to understand it all.

39473426.review:
[I actually really liked Farbor]




Creeper world 3 is fantastic. It's a game that blurs the already murky lines between RTS, TBS, and Tower Defense. It's real time, but you can pause at any point and queue up a hundred actions. It features a mindless, overwhelming enemy, but it's you who has to go on the offensensive against them, some have described it as a tower offense game.

The core mechanics are nice and tight. Creep functions in slightly different ways on each map, so you may need a restart or two per world to ascertain the best line of action, but this only adds to the enjoyment. It's rare that you feel like you're simply overpowering the enemy, more, you have to outsmart the map. Slight alterations in how resources are distributed and the exact positioning of emitters, subspace slips, digitalis trails, runner spawns, air denial zones, and BLOODY SPORES mean every map requires a unique strategy, not to mention how the game's decently sized campaign features a number of levels with fun, unique gimmicks, such as the creep rolling around the map, periodically overwhelming your defenses, to trying to defend a base about to be DP'd by two tidal waves of the stuff. Some gimmicks do feel a bit cheaper than others, in some missions the exposition will tell you "do X, if Y happens you'll fail", but then it turns out that X was impossible or you can't prevent Y. It's an annoying tweest the first time around, but after that the levels are fine.

The story is very take-it-or-leave-it. I haven't played either of the originals, but the story seemed to be internally confused in ways the originals wouldn't have helped. The ending is very underwhelming in every sense of the word, personally I thought Farbor was the best level in the game (this is a very controversial level) and would have made a much better finale. Still, it's perfectly fine to simply ignore the story, the gameplay is more than 100 times enough to cover it.

I'm not saying it's for everyone, this is a very slow paced RTS, as previously mentioned it encourages constant pausing and a few resets to figure out the level, and your level of micro is very limited, but speed nuts will still have a blast as there is a slight online competitive element to see how fast you can beat the level, although if all these results of 6 seconds aren't bugged I'll eat my hat. What I'm saying is it's not starcraft 2, it'd be more of a spellforce pace on an easy, large map without pausing.

After the excellent campaign, there is plenty more fun to be had. You can play a variety of premade maps in further, non-story paths, and there is both TWO procedural map generators, AND a highly in-depth custom map maker with built-in sharing to boot. (In-depth to the degree where some cutom maps let you play as the creep, somehow.)

Overall, if you'd like an engrossing, fun indie RTS where the levels feel more like puzzles than Clicks Per Second races, and the novelty of fighting a liquid (it never gets old) you should definitley give this a shot.
